B00005JOVH|2.0|DISCLAIMER: this review contains spoilers that may ruin your viewing of this film for those of you who are counting on this review to tell you whether or not to see it. If you wish for surprises, do not read this review, if you don't mind knowing what happens or my opinion on it, then please read on.          Jean is back... Mad as a hatter. Humans have developed a \\"Cure\\" for the \\"Mutant problem,\\" and... and...     Well, as far as the plot goes, it isn't all that for such a highly anticipated movie. But not to fret, the title, \\"The last stand\\" refers to a point in the movie where the last of the X-men stand together to prevent the brotherhood from entering a facility, in other words, not only are they in the midst of working on the final X-men movie [X4], but the producers/creators are also thinking up of spin off movies [Wolverine the movie is being considered as of this date]. The X-men series is far from dead. Now that I've put you at ease about the title, and hope for the next movie, let me tell you about this one.    Note: I've never been a fan of sequels, but X2 is one of the best sequels I've ever seen, since it introduced so many new mutants and left such a good storyline open with a few plot twists and blah blah blah. I really liked X2's imagination. X3 however...     While watching the movie, I got the vibe after the first 15 minutes that this movie was made solely to flick off the characters who's actors just didn't want to be on the project [after such a poor run in X1, Cyclopes just never got back in the game... sadly he leaves us, and we never truly see him leave]. Don't get me wrong, watching Jean as a child in the first 5 minutes of the movie was great, but when she came back in a dazed state and scott is... obliterated... It just didn't really get any better than the first scene. [I did wonder why storm didn't go the way of the dodo seeing as how halle berry did put up a small fuss about it in the begining of production of this movie [but she signedon anyway]].     Not only does cyclopse die, but so does patric stewart. Now, being a big fan of his, I was... appalled and more than a little disappointed when he left in the film, and I was more than just a little put out knowing Nightcrawler is NOT in this movie. But enough of what went wrong for me in the movie theatre; allow me to mention other points of the movie.    Finally after much awaited time, Wolverine is not the center of attention [Sadly, no one really is in this film]. True they've strayed quite a bit from the cartoon's version of X-men, but it's still pretty nice. Ice man and pyro go in for a showdown, as does that girl who walks through walls, and Colossisiss... whatever the heck that metal man's name is, team up together as well as some other goodies. However, after the third installment of the movies, Gambit still has not come onto the scene. But in his place we've got a much more blue character who lightens one's face up whenever he comes onto the screen with his beautiful acting and wonderful dialogue... but, just as Yoda's 30 second light saber fight in episode II was the only good reason to see that film, they almost pulled the same thing here, as Beast's 10 second fight is pretty sweet to see. Thankfully, the acting is so much better than the star wars franchise, and there are a few more reasons to watch this film.    With all that said, let me get back to Jean. She is... \\"Reincarnated\\" or something, they didn't really make that clear how she's still alive, however I will note that while watching her story unfold I suddenly smiled as a thought came to me as Xavier is \\"Trying\\" to explain what's going on with her,     \\"They're making this up as they go along...\\"    This was yet another vibe I got while watching the movie. I don't know about the rest of the public but I love plot lines and stories that provoke thought! The first X-men did this and mixed in enough action to leave one's eyes popping out for a sequel. X2 did an even better job and killed two birds with one stone, not only moving character pieces around the board, but also explaining wolverine a little better. X3 is little more than a bridge to X4 which hopefully... will be so the best of them all.    Now I really liked X2 because you got to see alot more of every mutant's power, even if it was for a few seconds. They tried to do the same thing here but, with so much to look at, one finds that most of the so called \\"Powers\\" the mutants have in this movie just aren't as imaginative. In fact other than the main villains [Jugant ect ect], there are none that catch the eye, or are worth mentioning on this review. True, there are more villains with super powers out there, just none of them as good, or shown to be as good.     Allow me to sum all this up.    I give this film 2 stars for it's sheer lack of effort. I give it to the actors for being such good sports and though it does seem at times that they really are making up their own lines as they go, they still acted like their characters. Beast was really nice to look at, and of course Who can't wait to see Wolverine and Jean go at it in the lab room? Come on, be honest now...   But frankly the story just wasn't cutting the mustard on this one, and with the excess of mutants, you never really did see alot of powers adequately. True there are a few good fighting scenes at the end of the movie, but not enough to warrant another star. X2 showed almost all of the powers for a bunch of little kids, why couldn't they do the same thing for a bunch of older meaner bad guys?   I did not like that this movie had a flavour of, \\"Let's get rid of some people today,\\" throughout the movie, as well as if the writers were saying, \\"Let's do this, even though there's no reason, but let's do it anyway.\\" Now, I could handle a few really good deaths that are dramatic, but most of the deaths were just plain ludicrous.     NOTE: the movie ends with a small sliver of hope, but not enough to warrant a sequel. watch themovie through the credits so that you can have a glimmer of hope for what is to come.    I am not bashing the acting, the directing or the special effects [Magneto moving the San Fran bridge is pretty cool to look at]. I'm just saying I expected more from a third installment from what seemed to be an almost better series than the current Spiderman films, however I'm just not so sure anymore with its lack of... Imagination and some key characters. Nightcrawler and Gambit, where'd they go?     While this movie is entertaining the first time you watch it, you'll either love it or hate it. Out of all three X-men movies, X2 is the best so far, because the last stand is a step back.
B0002IQNAG|5.0|\\"Dawn of the Dead\\" is a damn near perfect sequel to \\"night\\" and is undoubtedly one of the richest, satirical, doomy and apocalyptic horror movies ever filmed. No one can do social commentary via horror movie as well as romero, and his sense of the absurd and subtle yet scathing critique of consumerism is amusing and not at all pretentious. The sequence in which the biker gang breaks into the zombie infested mall is probably one of the most memorable scenes I've ever seen in any film, in the horror genre or outside of it. A particularly unsavory member of the group gets his intestines torn out by a zombie while getting his blood pressure checked, and it looks utterly real and not at all fake or cheesy. When one of the group is bitten on a 'truck raid' and turns into a zombie underneath a blanket in their hideout, he slowly pulls it from his face and the effect is really stomach churning and frightening. this is not just for horror fanatics, but anyone who loves an entertaining yet substantive film. Needless to say if you ARE a horror fan, you can't be worthy of the name till you see this utterly flawless and well executed masterpiece.

In a sense they want to go back to how things were before because they might want to recapture that spark the relationship once had or recapture the youth they once had as they feel themselves getting older and closer to their inevitable demise. <br /> <br />But before I make this sound like it's one of those depressing love stories to rival the likes of Verhoeven's adaptation of Jan Wolkers' Turkish Delight, I should tell them to relax, it's not like that at all. B000006NUW|5.0|Some have complained about the mono mix but for me this makes the set an even more fantastic trip down memory lane. B000002I25|4.0|To be honest, I never intended to buy this, or any other, Doors CD. I thought I would be best off with just my one-disc best of. But when I saw their debut at my local record store for ten bucks, I couldn't pass it up.<br />1. Break On Through (to the Other Side): 10/10. Classic Doors rocker with some very vivid imagery about the unknown. Starts things off in the right direction.<br />2. Soul Kitchen: 8/10. A kinda spooky song about sex (a dominant theme on this album). I like it, very underrated.<br />3. The Crystal Ship: 8/10. A haunting ode to drugs that finds its way on many compilations. Again, it's good.<br />4. Twentieth Century Fox: 10/10. Anybody besides me love the title? Anyway, it's a clever rocker about a hot woman and another one of the Doors' most underrated.<br />5. Alabama Song (Whiskey Bar): 5.5/10. One of the few songs that doesn't really work. Turns out that a show tune doesn't sound too good reworked by a rock band.<br />6. Light My Fire: 10/10. Contreversy central. It got them banned from the Ed Sullivan Show due to its sexually explicit lyrics and the line \\"Girl, we couldn't get much higher\\" (thought to be about drugs). Its length (7:08) was also contreversial. Shows that guitarist Robbie Krieger and organist Ray Manzarek could actually be talented instrumentalists if they tried. Oh, and I love the line \\"And our love become a funeral pyre\\".<br />7. Back Door Man: 10/10. You know it's a good cover when it gives the original a run for its money. And Back Door Man does just that, with an added second verse. Jim's menacing vocals are absoluetly perfect for Willie Dixon's dark lyrics. Fits in with the album thematically quite well.<br />8. I Looked At You: 6/10. WHAT? After all the good stuff (With the exception of Alabama song) that happened on the first side, we get THIS? Damn, if this isn't a paint-by-numbers tune I don't know what is. But it isn't bad, either... just not good.<br />9. End of the Night: 8/10. That's more like it. Spooky, haunting and impressive. I wish this song hadn't disappeared from the Doors' catalogue. Oh well.<br />10. Take It As It Comes: 5.5/10. Another lesser cut. And it's an undignified intro to...<br />11. The End: 10/10. (Actually, more like 10[...]/10).<br />You either love or hate the Doors, and this song is used as an argument for either side. Some people think it's just the ramblings of a raving drunk stretched out to twelve minutes and accompanied by low-key music played with all the talent of a garage band. Others (me included) see it as a haunting, dark poem, an exploration into the mind of an extremely tortured man. But that's just me. This and Riders On the Storm are Jim Morrison at his most poetic.<br />Ave: 8.27. A good debut album, but some tracks are pretty bad.<br />One thing I love about the Doors is how they were an alternative to what was going on in '67 musically. This was the year of such flower-power albums as Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band, Magical Mystery Tour, Between the Buttons, Are You Experienced... and here we've got Jim, singing about sex, death, the unknown and drugs. In other words, he explains the happy little seamy underbelly of the counterculture (so would that make him counter-counterculture?) So if you want some of the darkest music this side of the Velvet Underground, go after the Doors!hadn't disappeared from the Doors' catalogue. Oh well.  10. Take It As It Comes: 5.5/10. Another lesser cut. And it's an undignified intro to...  11. The End: 10/10. (Actually, more like 10[...]/10).  You either love or hate the Doors, and this song is used as an argument for either side. Some people think it's just the ramblings of a raving drunk stretched out to twelve minutes and accompanied by low-key music played with all the talent of a garage band. Others (me included) see it as a haunting, dark poem, an exploration into the mind of an extremely tortured man. But that's just me. This and Riders On the Storm are Jim Morrison at his most poetic.  Ave: 8.27. A good debut album, but some tracks are pretty bad.  One thing I love about the Doors is how they were an alternative to what was going on in '67 musically. This was the year of such flower-power albums as Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band, Magical Mystery Tour, Between the Buttons, Are You Experienced... and here we've got Jim, singing about sex, death, the unknown and drugs. In other words, he explains the happy little seamy underbelly of the counterculture (so would that make him counter-counterculture?) So if you want some of the darkest music this side of the Velvet Underground, go after the Doors!

0385336691|4.0|The new Lee Child is, of course, superb.  The quality of his writing is unerringly even and unerringly high.  He sets the standard for suspense writing.  The savvy behind his craft is apparent in The Hard Way, since the canvas is very narrow and potentially even claustrophobic.  The bulk of the novel is set in Manhattan, with strict geographic constraints.  The latter portion of the novel is set in East Anglia, but again, with constraints.  This could be a textbook case for aspiring crime writers--contrast this book with, e.g., Angels and Demons or The DaVinci Code.  All three novels are suspenseful, but look at the lengths (thematic, geographic, etc.) to which Dan Brown must go to create the suspense.  Lee Child achieves greater suspense within great constraints.  That could be part of the definition of masterful genre writing.<br /><br />Now for the mini-protest.  Lee, we love you, but we need a more violent ending.  A major catharsis requires a major blood-letting.

B0001HAISG|5.0|The mixed reviews for P.J. Hogan's 2003 hit \\"Peter Pan\\" leave you wondering if adults should be permitted to give a bad rating to a children's film. The vast majority of the reviews were positive ones, as the reviewers either liked the film themselves, or were convinced that it would be very entertaining viewing for children. The negative reviews came from adult critics who found little \\"personal\\" enjoyment and never really bothered about the children factor.    I only bring this up because J. M. Barrie's play, while addressing early adolescent angst, was actually intended for adult audiences who presumably would be prompted to retrospectively analyze the angst of their own dim past. Thanks to the toning down of Barrie's basic theme in the Disney and Mary Martin versions, \\"Peter Pan\\" became almost exclusively a children's story. Then along came Hogan's version, which fused the thematic emphasis of the original with the children's entertainment emphasis of the others.     Meaning that the film hits a home run with three very distinct target audiences. Once thing for sure is that this spectacular adaptation has almost universal appeal to preteen children, they will watch it countless times and you can't go wrong buying or renting it for that age group. And perceptive adolescents struggling with their own growing up process should relate to it. And finally, those adults (particularly males) who have consciously resisted the growing up process their entire lives should connect to this film like few others.     But if you don't belong to these three groups you will wonder what all the fuss is about. The answer is that this film uniquely focuses on the maturation process, which most girls embrace about sixth grade and most boys resist until 9th grade (and would resist even longer if girls were not luring them with the most obvious benefit of growing up). Some boys stubbornly hold out like Peter Pan, usually because they do not have a Wendy to pull them forward, and when they finally surrender and move forward into adulthood, they are aware that they are abandoning something precious and will look back with regret on the moment for the rest of their lives.     Now with that issue addressed this is \\"Peter Pan\\" and virtually everyone knows the story. It is a live action version superior to the stage version if only because it is unburdened by the play's odd cross-dressing tradition and the preschool Disney fusion of bad songs and lame slapstick humor. The production design should blow away all viewers, child and adult, with a dreamy Maxfield Parrish Victorian look and Barrie's treasure-map Neverland. The pacing is fast and Hogan shows a respectful grasp of how an imaginative child would visualize things while reading Barrie's story.     \\"Peter Pan\\" is really Wendy's story and there is no fault to find in Rachel Hurd-Wood's performance, which would be good enough to carry the film but fortunately is not required to do so. Wendy is second only to Wonderland's Alice as the bravest literary heroine of all time and Hogan nicely incorporates the many admirable qualities of her character into the story.    Jeremy Sumpter's Peter is far more obnoxious than appealing, but isn't that what you would expect from a boy who refuses to grow old.     Ludivine Sagnier's Tinkerbell provides comic relief to go with her homicidal tendencies; only adults want cute, children want pretend-nasty and this Tink is worthy of Barrie's original characterization. The \\"save Tink\\" audience chant is nicely incorporated into a full-cast montage.    Hook is played with a controlled zest by Jason Isaacs, not quite the self-parody of a Gary Oldham performance but his restraint is exactly what is needed.     Adults and children know that \\"Peter Pan\\" isn't so much suspension of disbelief as it is an exercise in self-knowing whimsy. You know that the mix of fairies, pirates, Indians and ticking crocodiles are devices designed to obscure the difficult facts of growing older.If you can't go with it then you surrendered something a long time ago that Peter is still stubbornly holding onto.    Then again, what do I know? I'm only a child.
B00004XQP4|4.0|News Flash!!!  Green Day = Punk band; Led Zepplin = Rock band.  COMPLETELY DIFFERENT GENRES. COMPLETELY DIFFERENT MUSIC made for COMPLETELY DIFFERENT core audience.  But both bands have a particular type of genius, and yes, both bands will be legendary when all is said and done.  I appreciate the musical talent of Led Zepplin, as they are truly masters of their instruments.  But I can also appreciate the true talent of Green Day as well, particularly evident in the lyrics of Billie Joe. Print out a few select Green Day song lyrics (Minority, Warning, even Macy's Day Parade) and it reads like a poem. Like something you have said, or have always wanted to say, to a parent, a cop, a lover, a friend, to God, or even to yourself. They know their audience and understand the thoughts and emotions. That's the whole point in punk music!!  So obviously, LZ fans, this music is not for you, so just back off and let GD fans enjoy their music without being told they have no brain.

B000068CNX|5.0|Welcome to the sophomore season of Friends. This is where the show and its stars truly exploded onto the national consciousness. With the advent of season the second, the cast and crew had finally hit their full stride. Standouts were David Schwimmer and Jennifer Aniston as Ross and Rachel and Lisa Kudrow as Phoebe. The Ross and Rachel romance was the strong impetus of the season and had the fans very much invested in the goings-on of the star-crossed duo. But there was still ample room for the other four characters to shine. Kudrow was exceptional in episodes such as The One Where Heckles Dies and The One Where Old Yeller Dies. The best-friend relationship of Joey and Chandler is delved into in The One With the Prom Video and later in a three- episode arc (with a memorable guest star performance by Adam Goldberg). This season also introduced Monica's second greatest love and very good acting foil, Dr. Richard Burke (as superbly, intelligently played by Tom Selleck). Brooke Shields owes her resulting sitcom to her guest star turn in The One After the Super Bowl. But Jean-Claude Van Damme, Julia Roberts and Chris Isaak left fans with a tepid feeling. It goes to show that Friends is best when it's just about the six characters.<br /><br />Highlight episodes are:<br /><br />The One with Ross's New Girlfriend - the season 2 opener finds Ross and Julie an item, much to the chagrin of Rachel; Chandler goes to Joey's old tailor and is taken advantage of; Phoebe cuts Monica's hair ala Dudley Moore.<br /><br />The One with Five Steaks and an Eggplant - the six are divided over money issues; Chandler picks up a wrong number on his phone and hooks up with a hot girl (the denouement to that storyline is gutbustingly funny).<br /><br />The One Where Ross Finds Out - a drunken Rachel leaves a message on Ross's phone; Monica is Chandler's new trainer, a fact he soon regrets; Phoebe's date won't put out (but he is Joey's god).<br /><br />The One With the Prom Video - an old video tape reveals a college-going Ross and high-schoolers Monica and Rachel (the debut of fat Monica and one of my favorite Chandler jokes \\"so how many cameras were actually on you?\\"); Phoebe states her lobster theory; Joey buys Chandler a friendship bracelet which Chandler doesn't want to wear; Monica is in need of a loan (check out the restaurant manager interviewing Monica right after the opening credits); this is truly a great episode.<br /><br />The One Where Ross and Rachel...You Know - well, it's pretty self-explanatory; also, this is where Monica meets Richard (wherein Richard expounds on the intricacies of the head tilt and the head bob).<br /><br />The One Where Old Yeller Dies - her mom had lied to naive Phoebe about the endings of sad films; Chandler and Joey bond with Richard; Ross freaks out Rachel with his long-term family plans.<br /><br />The included special features here improve upon the first season's. This time, there are 2 episodes with producers commentary (The One With the List and The One With the Prom Video). The box set also contains an interactive map to Monica and Rachel's pad, a friends of Friends video guestbook, a trivia quiz and a dvd-exclusive, uncut version of the Smelly Cat music video. Not bad.<br /><br />There's a reason this show was so well-loved and so much lauded by fans and critics alike. Come sit in for a fun chemistry lesson, as taught by Professors Aniston, Cox, Kudrow, LeBlanc, Perry and Schwimmer.<br /><br />Some fun trivia facts about Friends:<br /><br />The first person approached by the casting crew for Friends was David Schwimmer, the second was Lisa Kudrow.<br /><br />When Matthew Perry auditioned for Friends, he had just shot a pilot for a sitcom about baggage handlers in the year 2020, which fortuitously fell thru.<br /><br />The first cast member to star in a Hollywood movie is Marcel the Monkey.<br /><br />The original concept of the show was to star Joey, Monica, Ross and Rachel. Chandler and Phoebe were only supposed to be supporting roles.<br /><br />The record label wouldn't release the Rembrandts' album unless the band recorded a full-length version of \\"I'll Be There For You.\\" The Rembrandts were reluctant to release the Friends' title tune because the band members felt the song didn't mesh with what they were doing musically.<br /><br />The pilot is the only episode that shows in its entirety the opening credits sequence of the cast frolicking in the fountain. For the rest of the episodes, NBC insisted that scenes from various episodes be pulled into the opening credits, fearing that some viewers might not relate with hip, young folks splish-splashing in a fountain.sed to be supporting roles.<br /><br />The record label wouldn't release the Rembrandts' album unless the band recorded a full-length version of \\"I'll Be There For You.\\" The Rembrandts were reluctant to release the Friends' title tune because the band members felt the song didn't mesh with what they were doing musically.<br /><br />The pilot is the only episode that shows in its entirety the opening credits sequence of the cast frolicking in the fountain. B000F5GO0A|4.0|To be honest, when I think of Elephant 6 bands I don't usually think of Balkan folk music. But with the release of Beirut's \\"Gulag Orkestar,\\" I may have to revise my thinking.<br /><br />This new band consists of teenage musician Zach Condon, along with people from Neutral Milk Hotel and A Hawk and a Hacksaw, making bittersweet folkpop and danceable marches. Imagine a band of slightly drunk gypsies on parade, and you'll have the general idea of how it sounds.<br /><br />It opens slow, with a gentle piano and blaring horns. The title track meanders in circles and finally dies away... only to be reborn as a swaying march. Halfway through, Condon joins in with some mournful wails and equally mournful singing.  That turns around in \\"Prenzluerberg,\\" where the singing is just as melancholy, but the music is a cheerier march.<br /><br />From there on, the trio tries out those styles and everything in between -- rattly folk with tambourines and horns, danceable folkpop, and tinkly klezmer music. Yes, tinkly klezmer. They get downright happy in \\"Scenic World,\\" a colorful glockenspiel song that is just barely grounded by some quick violins.<br /><br />After that, \\"Gulah Orkestar\\" is pretty upbeat, with a string of swaying marches and upbeat folk acoustics. The album's finale is a bit of a head-scratcher, though. \\"After the Curtain\\" is a relatively bare-bones song with Condon singing over applause and a dancing glockenspiel. I don't know how to fit that one in.<br /><br />Basically this album is what happens when an American teenager drops out and crosses Eastern Europe, soaking up the folk music as he goes.<br /><br />And it's a good thing Condon's musical talents are being backed by experienced musicians, so we can get a bittersweet, atmospheric taste of whatever he heard there. The main problem is that the less folky songs don't really fit in -- without them, the album would have been a lot better. But as it is, it's a remarkable achievement.<br /><br />Condon has a pretty deep voice for someone so young, and he fills it with the longing and beauty that traditional singing often has. And he's assisted by some very talented musicians: Jeremy Barnes and Heather Trost, both of whom work in the psych-folk band A Hawk and a Hacksaw. So of course, they have a good ear for this sort of thing.<br /><br />So how do they manage? Soundwise, it's like someone took the gypsy out of Gogol Bordello and slapped it on Neutral Milk Hotel. The songs are brimming with violins, horns, accordion, mandolin, pianos, ukeleles, glockenspiel and many others. These instruments are so smoothly blended that it sounds like at least a dozen people are playing at any one time, and that they've played this music their whole lives.<br /><br />\\"Gulag Orkestar\\" is a pretty, heart-tugging album that will make you think of quaint European villages in the springtime. Definitely worth listening to, many times.on has a pretty deep voice for someone so young, and he fills it with the longing and beauty that traditional singing often has. And he's assisted by some very talented musicians: Jeremy Barnes and Heather Trost, both of whom work in the psych-folk band A Hawk and a Hacksaw. So of course, they have a good ear for this sort of thing. <br /> <br />So how do they manage? Soundwise, it's like someone took the gypsy out of Gogol Bordello and slapped it on Neutral Milk Hotel. The songs are brimming with violins, horns, accordion, mandolin, pianos, ukeleles, glockenspiel and many others. These instruments are so smoothly blended that it sounds like at least a dozen people are playing at any one time, and that they've played this music their whole lives. <br /> <br />\\"Gulag Orkestar\\" is a pretty, heart-tugging album that will make you think of quaint European villages in the springtime. Definitely worth listening to, many times.

B000E6ESL2|5.0|Wow! I'm always pleasantly surprised when I see that a few brave souls are still making films for intelligent adults. In recent years, the rare treats--for those of us who demand more from movies than we usually get--have included MULHOLLAND DRIVE, SWIMMING POOL, MEMENTO, THE JACKET, GOOD NIGHT AND GOOD LUCK, CAPOTE, BROKEBACK MOUNTAIN, A HISTORY OF VIOLENCE, and...STAY. <br /> <br />This is a fascinating film, and one that demands close attention and multiple viewings. I watched it on the advice of friends whose opinions I trust, and I'm glad I did. Watch closely, and you'll see a great deal. I won't spoil the payoff, but the title of this review is a crucial line of dialogue, spoken by Ewan McGregor near the end of the film. The whole world, indeed! <br /> <br />I'm disappointed that STAY got such negative reviews and did so poorly at the box office, but I can't say I'm surprised. The new generations of American critics and film audiences have been conditioned to expect loud explosions and crude, adolescent humor as entertainment, and a film like this is obviously going to confuse and bore them. But for those of you out there who actually know who Hitchcock, Kurosawa, Antonioni, Fellini, Peter Greenaway and David Lynch are (not to mention Ambrose Bierce), you're in for a feast. There's more going on here than in most of the usual Hollywood \\"product.\\" Stay with STAY--you won't regret it.
B00005JOVH|5.0|A cure has been found for the \\"disease\\" of having mutative genes and this cure is offered to any mutant desirous of being normal. Very quickly, this becomes a hot-button issue for non-mutants and mutants alike as the all-important question surfaces: does being a mutant constitute being diseased? Magneto, not only a mutant advocate but one who believes that mutants are the superior life form on earth, vehemently wants nothing of the cure and, in fact, seeks to annihilate the root of the cure - that being a little boy named Jimmy (Leech), himself a mutant who nullifies other mutants' powers. Magneto also continues to gather his power base, from which to wage his ongoing war against the \\"lesser\\" humanity. Simultaneous to these events, Jean Grey returns, but oh so terribly altered. She is now styled the (Dark) Phoenix and her psychic and telekinetic powers have increased exponentially and are controlled by an amoral persona. The ever beleaguered X-Men find themselves at a crossroad. Due to a catastrophic tragedy, the Xavier School for Gifted Students is in dire jeopardy of closing. Further, The X-Men are divided with the issue of the cure. Some, like Storm, believe there is nothing wrong with being a mutant. Some, like Rogue, just wants to fit in. But in the end, the X-Men must once more band together and protect humanity from Magneto's assaults.<br /><br />X-Men - The Last Stand pulls no punches. Key characters bite the big one in this possibly final installment, raising the angst level (as if it needed it) to new heights. X-Men has always been the comic book standard bearer for social issues and racial dynamics and this second sequel begs the question: what qualifies as humanity? And in comic book reality, with the supposition that mutants are real, as a \\"normal\\", how does one differentiate between persecution and self-preservation? Weighty matters for those who want to delve a little deeper. Me, I watch X-Men for the cool special effects.<br /><br />And what of the special effects? They are expertly awesome. The movie screen seems to show something impossible every 2 minutes and yet, these scenes are conveyed with fantastic realism. If a man could fly, if a woman could control the weather, if a man could manipulate metal - well, this is how it would look.<br /><br />I so enjoyed this movie, from start to finish. The principal actors have had 2 prior films to get to know their roles and by this third outing, they embody their characters with easy conviction. The movie's focus is again firmly on Wolverine and why not, as he's got his own film lined up? But Prof. Xavier, Storm, Magneto and Jean Grey are also given decent camera time. Secondary roles of import are Hank McCoy (the Beast), Bobby Drake (Iceman), and Kitty Pryde (Shadowcat). The cast of X-Men, the Brotherhood and other mutants is so large that short thrift is given to many characters. I wish more time had been devoted to Angel, Colossus, Mystique and Rogue. And I thought Multiple Man was a good guy? And where's Nightcrawler?<br /><br />Things to look for:  Magneto's awesome levitation of a massive bridge; the erudite Beast finally unleashed; that old staple, the Colossus/Wolverine fastball; Iceman vs. Pyro; and my personal favorite, Kitty Pryde takes on the unstoppable Juggernaut.<br /><br />Here's hoping that there's a fourth X-Men and that Gambit and/or Longshot are in it.<br /><br />Helpful hint: stick around until after the closing credits, there's more movie.pecial effects? B000E97Y6K|5.0|Okay, I admit it: I'm a little bit of a fanboy.  I think you have to be to some extent, though, when going into a movie knowing it's about a giant ape rampaging through New York.  I walked out of the theatre thinking this is the best movie I've ever seen, probably due to the mass assault on my senses.  I knew that idea would be tempered after reflection, but for reviewers to give this movie 1's & 2's is laughable.  What would they rate the Dungeons and Dragons, You Got Served, Kazaam, Gigli, Spice World or Jaws: the Revenge for crying out loud? <br /> <br />Although I don't think any Oscars will be shelled out for the acting in King Kong, I must disagree with those that say the performances were terrible.  I was not a Jack Black fan going into the movie, but I am more so now.  All the other roles were either done well or only suffered from a bit of mis-direction, if you can forgive the play on words.  And I've heard numerous reviewers say how bad the final line of the movie is.  Am I wrong, or isn't the last line taken straight from the original? <br /> <br />Speaking of nods to previous versions, I just had to make mention of the native stage scene.  (I haven't seen it previously mentioned, though I haven't read all 700+ reviews on this site either.)  The costumes for the natives on stage in New York looked very much like the true natives' costumes from the 70s version.  Fans of Kong had to chuckle at that. <br /> <br />As far as the movie's length goes, I had no problems with it.  When I'm shelling out $9 to see a movie, I'll take three hours over two any day, as long as I'm not bored.  I did not find myself squirming once, unlike Lord of the Rings...and I'm very much a Tolkien fan!  Of course, with three hours to work with, I understand those reviewers asking for a little more character thought into just what is going on there at Skull Island.  On the other hand, they of course would have no idea and didn't seem to have much time to think about it. <br /> <br />The brontosaurus (or whatever they are exactly) pile-up, though a great idea, was a little cheesy for my tastes.  As many have already stated, the CGI was a little suspect here and too many people escaped certain death.  That is a problem I have with most action movies these days, though.  The certain death factor can be scaled back a little bit to make it both scary AND believable.  Only one character to my recollection simply found a crevice to hide in until the rolling thunder passed.  Did other reviewers miss the folks that were pulverized into oblivion in that scene, though?  And I understand that there was a need to spur the beasts into a stampede, but enough with the raptors already.  Kong or one of the T-Rex's would have sufficed. <br /> <br />My biggest grief with the movie was the bat scene.  Using one as a hang-glider was just plain bad.  Luckily, the scene is short and thus a little more forgivable.  Don't get me wrong, though.  Whereas the scenes in the city were the highlight of the previous movies, the jungle action was probably the pinnacle of this film, for good or ill.  The bugs scene, probably another nod to the original \\"snake pit\\" footage that was cut due to its grisliness (if I recall correctly) and subsequently lost to time, was utterly disturbing and the effects fantastic. <br /> <br />Speaking of effects, I agree with some reviewers that Kong himself seemed to have slightly varying sizes throughout the movie, but I'm not sure everyone is considering the beast's surroundings.  He's obviously going to look bigger inside a New York theatre as compared to the top of the Empire State Building.  I can certainly forgive a few feet here or there if it's done for good cinematic effect. <br /> <br />Another question mark is the taxi cab chase.  As fun as it was to watch, just what was the character trying to accomplish?  Instead of leaving Kong to his business of smashing a bus all to pieces, he leads him on a romp through the city causing untold amounts of carnage and property damage.  I guess you could argue that he had the best of intentions (draw the beast away from the bus) and, again, didn't have a lot of time to think about the repercussions. <br /> <br />So you must be wondering, after all of the low points I've detailed and the explanations I've given for dubious areas of the film, why I was so high on it walking out.  It cannot be fully explained in words.  The detail of the early city scenes, the character building on the boat, the dramatic build up to the finding of the isle, the sweeping landscapes of the jungle, the terror of the native attack, the dinosaur fight scenes, the vertigo of the airplane assault scenes all must be experienced (preferably in the theater) to be understood.  I even enjoyed the \\"ice skating\\" scene, but then I'm a sucker for whimsical brutes. <br /> <br />Though you can debate the nuances and certain parts of the storyline, I can't see how anyone can reasonably argue that Peter Jackson did a disservice to the Kong franchise with this incarnation.  I would be inclined to say just the opposite: that the atmosphere of the film alone was worth the price of admission.  But hey, take any review with a grain of salt, especially from a self-proclaimed fanboy.

6305897786|2.0|Many people, when discussing this film, seem to stand on eithier the 'no action = stinks' side of the podium or the 'love Polanski = love everything he touches' side. <br />I myself am neither. I am a Polanski fan but felt 'Ninth Gate' is a somewhat failed attempt at the psychological horror Polanski is capable of. Many works of Polanski, both new and old, excell head and shoulders above this film. Don't misunderstand me. There are nice moments in this film. Some people may fall in love so much with these moments they tend to look over the idiotic moments that can be found here. <br />For those of you wandering how good the film is - please rent first and make up your own mind before buying. There are moments in the film that succumb to Hollywood popish cinema - such as two ridiculous scenes involving a woman floating on air (subtlety be gone) and the horrid burning scene near the finale (way over the top). <br />I really tried to keep this film in my collection of Polanski. But next to films such as 'Repulsion', 'Knife In The Water', 'The Pianist' and others, it seems to fall short. You can see the Polanski touch around the corners here but it seems as if this were more an attempt to cash in on the glory days of his early horror works but reformed for a modern audience - it fits well in with today's hollywood horror, with or without the action. <br />Gladly Polanski reveals, through 'The Pianist', that he can still grab an audience and do so in a realistic gripping manner - a true life horror of sorts - no goofy moments here. For those who are better chilled by a sense of realism, whether in fiction, non-fiction, fantasy context or otherwise, may want to look elsewhere in the Polanski library. Horror fantasy works best in subtle strokes.
B000FBGBPC|5.0|I loved the 3 Days Grace debut and I love this album just as much. Great stuff.  <br />So... being a night shift worker, i woke up early to buy this CD... and it was so worth loosing the extra sleep. This is a solid effort... and it is really hard to pick a bad song of the bunch. A touch of grace with an angry edge... indeed.
1591396190|3.0|For those of you interested I strongly recommend the article by the authors (Value Innovation: The Strategic Logic of High Growth, W. Chan Kim, Renee Mauborgne, HBR July 2004) which presented the same concept with fewer examples- it will save you time and money.  <br />I do like the Value Innovation concept. But as the authors highlight you cannot create sustainable competitive advantage this way; the new \\"value-curve\\" can be copied easily by the competitors.  <br /> <br />Also, the concept and framework are not entirely new; all of the examples presented in the book can be explained via the old and true concept of knowing your market/consumers' needs/wishes, and the trend of changes in your market/consumers' needs/wishes. If a firm is truly in-touch with their market/consumers, it can constantly create new sources of value, and change its value proposition as market changes. <br /> <br />The real problem is that firm do not stay in-touch, and that they often fall in love with their original value proposition. No new framework can change this problem. The only cure is financial troubles. Then, the firm keeps a new look at its market and consumers' needs/wishes, and when you reach this point you really don't need a new frawework. Although, the new framework might make the task of presenting your finding to management easier.

B000AYEL6U|5.0|I recently viewed North and South.  This was a beautifully performed.  I have not read the book and will defer such comparisons to those who have.  I felt that this story explored many relationships that had great significance outside those of the love story itself.  There was the self doubt of Mr. Hales regarding the church, the fondness of a long time servant that \\"stepped out of line\\", the tight relationship of a mother and son, the begging of a daughter (Fanny) to be noticed by her family, the struggle and rise of the middle class, and the gradual growth of friendship between the \\"master\\" and Higgins.  I feel that these relationships brought color and depth to the otherwise lovable but predicable romantic aspect. <br /> <br />I found it interesting that Margaret was often standing in her scenes.  Also, she looked down alot when lost for words.  This may have been a deliberate acting gesture to express the emotional load that she assumed thru the story.  I would have liked to see more emphasis on Thorton visiting Higgins.  This is the first time in the movie that he noticably smiles--at the begging child.  He was obviously reaching into his past.  It was from then on that he became more \\"human\\" and softer gestures along with smiling were incorporated into his character. <br /> <br />The only other comment I have is on the final scene.  It is a lovely scene at the train station--very soft and touching.  However, his physically turning away because he couldn't bear to see her go back to the \\"London\\" train could have been emphasized.  This,with the subsequent realization of seeing her reflection in the window along with the relief that she had not rejected him again, could have been stronger. The final shot showed her gazing out the window--NOT SMILING, and him looking down.  I would have liked to see them at least happier.  Having said that, I truly enjoyed the performances and recommend North and South highly.
B000002H97|4.0|Metallica's self-titled album was their entrance to the mainstream and bade farewell to their more epic thrash origins.  While it might not be as good as Master Of Puppets or Kill 'Em All, it is still a very good listen.  Metallica decided to write the polar opposite of their previous album, And Justice For All.  Instead of writing 9 songs of 63 minutes in length, Metallica wrote songs that were shorter but still were heavy and catchy.  To the people that said Metallica sold out- what is the problem with writing something that's catchy?   <br /> <br />Bob Rock is a large contributor to this album, although he did not play on the album.  Bob Rock did a wonderful job producing- all the instruments are loud and sound great.  Bob also steered Metallica from the excessively long riffs and bridges of their previous album so it is in many ways, better than Justice. <br /> <br />For all the reviews saying that this album is 'not metal', that's completely wrong.  The riffs, the main part of any Metallica song, are still heavy, and the solos are great.  The controversy is over The Unforgiven and Nothing Else Matters, two ballads that show a new side of Metallica.  Unlike the hair metallers before them, like Motley Crue, Metallica comes off as sincere and 'from the heart'.  James actually tries to sing, which isn't that bad. <br /> <br />Overall, this album is pretty good.  It is a great starting point for new Metallica fans, as it bridges the older stuff, as well as their later stuff, like Load and Reload.  Highy recommended!

B000002UJQ|5.0|Ok, so maybe 'stunning' isn't the first word that comes to mind when listening to the album for the first time.  Maybe 'interesting' is more appropriate.  But the album suddenly, on the second or even third listen, just grips you and blows you away.    The opening chords to 'Airbag' no longer sound clashed, but simply aggressive.  The meandering music and lyrics of 'Homesick Subterranean Alien' no longer sound without purpose, simply lost and isolated.  And the mumbling 'Exit music (for a film)' now sounds frustrated.    In fact, with every single listen, more and more of the magic of this album is revealed, more of the (in some cases) subtle emotion and overwhelming feeling of hopelessness and frustration shows through.  Every time the record presents something new.    And there is not one single track which could be removed from the album without depleting it in some way.  Similarly, I don't have a favourite, or least favourite song, nor any that I skip through when I listen to it.  The album is that good.  Every song is sublime, stunning, and terribly beautiful.    People have said that Radiohead will never top this record.  But why would they be able to? They have, in this album, made the best record ever.  They have created an album which is as near to being perfect as it is possible to be.  How can we expect them to top that?  In 'OK Computer' the band have found the perfect, delicate balance between oddity and appeal.  This shows as the album changes from the very 'non-mainstream' 'Exit Music (for a film)' straight to the pop-rock 'Let Down'.    And I'm not some die-hard Radiohead fan either.  Sure, I like 'The Bends' and 'Kid A', but I don't own all of their albums.  I haven't bought any of their work since the release of Kid A.  This isn't my favourite album, either - that award would go to 'Appetite for Destruction'.  So, in that respect, I'm a neutral who just recognises that this album is a masterpiece.    You have to buy this album.  In twenty, thirty years when you dig out all your old CDs, albums by 'Fall Out Boy', 'Kanye West' and 'Green Day' will seem unremarkable, if not rubbish.  But this album will not.  It is timeless.  When your kids start laughing at the kind of music you used to listen to, just play them this.  That'll shut them up.

B00005JNRY|4.0|My five year old enjoyed this one a lot, she was very entertained, so the target audience will probably be giving this a five star rating.<br /><br />I knocked it down a bit just because of the general cornyness (if that's a real word) of the movie, which also meant a bit contrived and a bit predictable, etc.<br /><br />However, I'll be buying the dvd and I do give it a strong recommendation, go take the kids to see it at the movies, it was wholesome and fun and all that.
B00004U2G4|5.0|I own 5 Jeff Beck albums and in a way, this one is the most fascinating of them.  Possibly because as a Led Zeppelin fan, this album is soundwise, a precurser to Led Zeppelin.  That being said, it has a life and fire all it's own.  Jeff Beck is one of the greatest guitarists ever to pick up the instrument.  The album keeps me whipping along, though I get a little lost on \\"Old Man River\\".   <br /> <br />\\"Shape of Things\\" is a great re-working of the Yardbirds tune.  This is the introduction of the world to Rod Stewart, who sings with a passion that does this song justice.  The song was also covered in this form by Gary Moore and Jimmy Page and the Black Crowes. <br /> <br />\\"Let Me Love You\\" is another great tune.  Comes in with a rocking guitar riff and contains some tasty guitar and vocal interplay between Beck and Stewart.   <br /> <br />\\"Morning Dew\\" fades in with a haunting sound  followed by a bass and drum beat before going into the song.  The song, while played in a major key, has an extremely haunting flavor to it.  A prime cut from the band. <br /> <br />\\"You Shook Me\\"-This is NOTHING like the Led Zeppelin version.  Jeff Beck boasts that he wanted to make the rudest and sickest sounds with his guitar on this song.  And he did that.  It is sad that this song became a major point of contension between Beck and Page when Page recorded his own version for Zeppelin.  Back on topic though, this is a great rendition of the song and is worth listening to just to juxtapose with Zeppelin. <br /> <br />\\"Old Man River\\"-Probably my least favorite track from the album.  In this case, the only real positive is the fact that Rod Stewart sings it with such passion.  Sadly, he hasn't sung with that kind of passion since his early solo/Faces days. <br /> <br />\\"Greensleeves\\"-Not familiar with the traditional version, but I love the way Beck takes some time to show off his skills on an acoustic guitar.  It has a very medieval and majestic feel to it.   <br /> <br />\\"Rock My Plimsoul\\"-Back to the straightahead blues rock.  Another track with vocal and guitar interplay between Beck and Stewart.  Beck's guitar playing was top notch here. <br /> <br />\\"Beck's Bolero\\"-An excellent instrumental featuring Jeff Beck, Jimmy Page, John Paul Jones and Keith Moon.  The interplay between Beck and Page alone make this one worthwhile, however everybody contributed greatly.  It is very evocative of early Zeppelin.  This track was not recorded during the \\"Truth\\" sessions.  There are some differing accounts to when it was recorded.  Probably in 1966 or 1967.  Another point of contension between Beck and Page.  Mainly over the writing credit.  This bolero rhythm was used on \\"How Many More Times\\" from Zeppelin I. <br /> <br />\\"Blues Deluxe\\"-The longest track on the album.  This is supposed to be the blues in a live setting, however, many believe that the audience was dubbed in to give it the feel of a live track.  However it is still a great track.  Being the longest song on the album, it has the feel of being improvised.  Joe Bonamassa also covered this song for his album of the same name.   <br /> <br />\\"I Ain't Superstitious\\"-IMO, the best track on the album.  The leads that Beck pulls out during the course of this song are great.  In many ways this is the tastiest sounding Beck's guitar playing has been during the course of this album.  Stewart's voice here shows that he was meant to be a bluesman.  And the grand finale capped this song off well.  Megadeth also covered this song for their 1986 album \\"Peace Sells...But Who's Buying\\".
0679422714|2.0|The greatest quality of this book is surely the research that was done and the previously inaccessible witnesses the authors were able to speak to. It would have been better had their project remained at that level to be incorporated into existing historical analysis.  <br /> <br />This book clearly breaks new ground but it does so in a way that fails to incorporate existing historical research into Mao and communist China. Certainly the argument that traditional historians have failed to understand the period and the man is legitimate, but it is difficult to believe that historians have failed quite so spectacularly, since the book does not claim to add a fresh insight to one specific historical event but to overturn established research on dozens of major historical flashpoints including the Long March, Lin Biao's death, and the power of the Gang of Four in Mao's last days. This makes it, at least, a bad historical work. <br /> <br />The fact that the authors demonstrate a prejudice in presenting their evidence makes it, moreover, a badly argued book. The horrors of Mao should speak for themselves yet the authors feel the need to remind us of his evil by minimizing the atrocities committed by others (Chiang Kai-shek for one). This double standard inserts doubt into our minds as to the accuracy of the information presentend, undermining the book's original intention.  <br /> <br />Finally the book is badly written in so much as it presents an implausible account of Mao. Half the book is devoted to his megalomania, incompetence, and general evil-ness while the other half is devoted to his acquisition of power. This dichotomy, between a man who achieved so much (by destroying so much) who is nevertheless bad at economics, bad at speaking, and in every way unlikable is never resolved and hence leaves one feeling hoodwinked.  <br /> <br />I have to give the book two stars because anyone interested in Mao or communist China should read it for the sake of all the new evidence the authors uncovered. The reader must be forewarned however that this should be the only reason he is reading the book.
B0009IW88A|5.0|Tim Burton's Batman is very much like Danny Elfman's score for it: over-the-top, obvious, and gaudy. Similarly, Nolan's Batman is like Hans Zimmer's and James Newton-Howard's music in that it is subtle, believable, and absolutely wonderful.     Batman Begins, in my own, humble, opinion, was one of the best movies last year only because it didn't seem to be written as \\"a super-hero movie\\" but instead as a uniquely human story whose protagonist just happened to be one Bruce Wayne. If you enjoyed the film, the music will not disappoint. With its especially dark and haunting feel, and occasional heart-pounding action sequences, the music matches the film perfectly. Underneath the low, dark, themes, exceptionally warm, lush, and strangely human string melodies occasionally emerge, helping to establish the fact that the focus of the movie truly is on the characters themselves and the individual relationships they have with one another. These motifs are spread out strategically through the soundtrack and are slightly scarce, making them all the more heartbreakingly beautiful when they do eventually surface.    As a huge fan of both Zimmer and Newton-Howard, it was especially entertaining for me to listen to the score and pick out the aspects of it that resembled more Zimmer's technique and more Newton-Howard's. I tend to enjoy James Newton-Howard's quieter works (such as the work he's done with M. Night Shyamalan) and Hans Zimmer's grander ones (like The Last Samurai) and was amazed how well these two styles meshed together. They complimented each other wonderfully and I was left wanting more. I only hope that the two will collaborate again in the future.     If you are sick of movies and the music that goes with them, that hit you over the head with the loud, grand, ostentatious, brass-filled themes, and are looking for something better, then Batman Begins is the soundtrack for you.

Callie, though not herself college-educated, has the adorable habit of noting grammatical errors and typos in the local newspaper that Willie owns, and she befriends Willie and even tries to disuade him from his \\"heathenistic\\" ways by dragging him off to her church, which he finds he actually enjoys.  Their relationship is one to be applauded and truly gives the reader a picture of what it must have been like to live in the Deep South in the 1970s in a way that makes one think.<br /><br />Though this novel doesn't have as much suspense as The Firm, A Time to Killer, or Runaway Jury, it's a novel worthy of many accolades and definitely worth the reader's time!<br /><br />BRAVO, MR. 6304696515|5.0|I am not often very interested in stories taking place in pre-industrial times. B0007OCG56|2.0|Spanglish was a movie that had all the elements necessary for a great romantic comedy and didn't live up to its potential. After watching the commercials for it on TV, with the overwight daughter, the alchoholic grandmother and the overall messed up but rich family, I felt the story left much to be desired overall and was incomplete.<br /><br />The story is narrated to us by Flor's daughter. Despite this, her character is left a blank throughout much of the story, being much more an object than a character. The main character of interest is, of course, the mother. She cannot speak English, however and there aren't any subtitles. Despite this, you imediately sympathise with her and she is much easier to understand than the rest of the cast.<br /><br />The family poses the largest problem. The father, first presented as a wimpy nice-guys-finish-last type is by the endthe same as when he started. He is so passive throughout the whole film you want to shake some sense into him. But they try to convince you he is perfect. The mother on the other hand is incredibly annoying, and by the end she hasn't changed one jot either. She's superficial, selfish and arrogant. The daughter was wonderful, but the ideas of her being overweight are dumped on you the first half-hour, than she disappears entirely from the story and appears again at the end for five minutes. Her problems have not been resolved either. The boy had nothing to do with anything and the grandmother suddenly says near the end 'I quit drinking a month ago' and that's that.<br /><br />Ultimately, the story was really about nothing more than a maid who went to work for some people and left. She didn't change their lives. They didn't change theirs. The story may very well not have happened. The only significant change was that of the daughter, which was told more than shown, and the daughter had such little involvement in the story in the first place, you find yourself not really caring.<br /><br />I did like the themes of sacrificing for your children and staying true to your culture and family. When her loveable daughter started to be become the all-American Valley-girl stereotype I felt truly appaled and was pleased at the way it was all resolved.<br /><br />In the end, it was an enjoyable movie. Long, but enjoyable. A rediculously large portion of it was spent with the huge fights between Flor and her employers, which was really silly and unneeded. So much was brought into the movie you kept waiting for any sort of resolution, but none ever came. When it ended, you have this feeling of, what was the point? I don't mind open endings, but these were serious oversights and huge plot holes. Why does it matter that he doesn't want his restautrant promoted to a four-star, and then after it gets promoted, he does nothing. Why was that even brough in? It was all very...anti-climactic.<br /><br />But for a weekend, this is a good movie to watch, with some nice romantic scenes and a feel-good quality overall.the themes of sacrificing for your children and staying true to your culture and family. B0007P0LPC|5.0|Nureyev had a wonderfully keen practical and artistic sense of how to produce the classical ballets.  Among other things, he realized the merits of enlarging the role of the male dancer, as did Balanchine, his quote to the contrary notwithstanding!(Male dancers who danced for him that I have trained with, tell me that when he said ballet is all about women, he was mostly referring to the concept of partnering, where the woman is prominently displayed;  he enjoyed working with male dancers very much, as we can see in his choreography.)  In this version, both principal dancers are given a great deal of choreography and, as one would expect from one of the world's most famous ballet duos, they dance magnificently!  Margot Fonteyn was always the quintessential ballerina, both on stage and off.  She was also a great balletic actress and did not like to be disturbed backstage during a ballet because she would stay in character.  She always peformed at her best, right up to the end of her very long career.<br />Some people have been surprised at the closeup of Nureyev in this at the begining of the first act; it shows the starkness of his makeup.  Actually, this type of makeup is often used for this role, but we usually don't see it in closeup!  It looks good at a distance.  It is all part of the fantasy aspect of Swan Lake.<br />Especially noteworthy is the adagio Nureyev dances at the end of act one.  Many dancers have bought this version just to see and study this!  It is one of the greatest moments in classical ballet!<br />Nureyev's handling of the corps de ballet is also fantastic.  I loved the geometric patterns he sets for them.  The corps also dances with great precision and passion.<br />The only subdued aspect of this version is that of the Rothbart character.  He is reduced to just a character role here.  Nureyev liked to have important character, non-dancing , roles in his ballets for balance, no doubt.<br />This recent transfer by DG is marvelous, both visually and acoustically.  I highly recommend this classic performance as a traditional Swan Lake.y.  I highly recommend this classic performance as a traditional Swan Lake.

B0006L16N8|3.0|...why it's simplistic bands like these that end up selling millions upon millions of albums and sell out concerts with tickets that cost $600 apiece. Nowadays, all you have to do is figure out what's popular in the music scene, assemble a group of people who are willing to devote their entire lives to playing boring, repetitive songs every night for the next few years, make a demo, send it to a major label, and you're set until the fads turn to another outlet. That's the mindset that got this particular band into the spotlight. Some people live and die by the name Coldplay, swearing upon the Bible itself that Chris \\"Christ\\" Martin (my nickname for him, seeing as he's become an international icon for almost nothing) and his band are the only reason they live. I even had to analyze the song \\"Fix You\\" in my English class, making me even more bitter against them and against my teacher for giving into the lies. Refreshing? Please. There are hundreds of bands out there just like this, some of them even better, that people have never heard of and aren't willing to listen to because they're too into their favorite trendy pop group. The only reason this band got popular is because they came around at the right time and made known their political views, rallying confused American/British young adults to their cause and branding them with the mark of Coldplay.The members of Coldplay aren't even all that talented, but they make music that sells and people believe that it means something to them. What really bugs me is that they refused multi-million dollar contracts from several large companies who wished to use their songs on commercials, claiming that they \\"wouldn't be able to live with ourselves if we sold the songs' meanings like that\\". Funny, their music already means little when you really think about it, because cliched metaphors and ambigious statements that  COULD have deep meaning are obviously a vie for mainstream signage.<br /><br />So now let's go through what elements of this band causes me to be so angry at them. Frontman Chris Martin is one of the major reasons this band is overrated and annoying. His voice is somewhat soothing and melodic, but he is no way a great vocalist. I can actually replicate his voice to almost exact specifications and play his short, repetitive piano pieces on the piano, proving that even an average teen can play this music. Guitar player Jon Buckland, while appearing on here more often than the previous albums, still doesn't playing very memorable (except maybe the lick from \\"Talk\\", which is enjoyable but EXTREMELY overdone, being played after every verse; in addition, the riff was taken from the Kraftwerk song \\"Computer Love\\", which is pretty pathetic in itself) and is pretty much useless, strumming repetitive three-chord riffs (an overused description, but the truth isn't always interesting) and not much else. Bassist/synthesist Guy Berryman provides some soothing ambience on most of the tracks but isn't that good as a bass player and it's probably better that he rarely makes an appearance, instead focusing on adding some texture to the music, as it badly needs it. Last and most likely least is drummer Will Champion, whose drumming does little more than keep the music from falling apart, and even then it barely does that job. But drumming isn't really important to this music, so I won't hold him responsible for that.<br /><br />Bottom line: I don't really mind the music all that much; in fact, it can be quite soothing and ethereal when I need to get to sleep or something (though I often prefer something heavy and fast to lull me into a slumber, ironically), but the things that this band stands for sparks my anger against them. It disturbs me how popular this band is when they just follow the trends, and meanwhile amazing bands that refuse to sell out gather dust in a distant, isolated European town playing to a small, dedicated crowd who know what real music is. So if you want a good, talentedband with a soft overtone and meaningful lyrics, then don't start here.<br /><br />Track Selections: \\"Talk\\", \\"Speed of Sound\\", and \\"Swallowed in the Sea\\"<br /><br />6/10ft overtone and meaningful lyrics, then don't start here.     Track Selections: \\"Talk\\", \\"Speed of Sound\\", and \\"Swallowed in the Sea\\"    6/10
B000EU1PKK|5.0|I have been a poor student for a long time, but recently I have started to have an income. When I found out the remasters of the helloween albums were coming out, I bought them all immediately.  I have been waiting to do this for a long time, and now is the perfect time for everyone.<br /><br />This particular remaster includes the original album plus the judas single, and then to add extra incentive, they added 7 b sides to a second disc.  The disc one has been re-mastered and sound crisp, and as fresh as the day they were originally penned.  It is the second disc that I want to stress as the best part of the new edition, and makes the investment worth it.  The two versions of ride the sky (remix and Live) are both nice, and murderer remix and guardian live are cool too, But the tracks Oernst Of Life and Metal Invaders from the DEATH METAL compilation are the weight of this remaster. This is the first time the track Oernst has been anywhere easly available to the public since 1984.  I have heard this song only once before this, but I did not have the 50-100 dollars to buy the vinyl Death Metal record to get it.  It is one of the first tracks ever layed down by helloween, and is a classic fast, loud metal song that is a unrecognized gem of the early mid 80's metal days.  The liner notes of this one also starts the story of the fledgling band, and has an interview with Michael Weikath (as do all of the re-masters series) that fills in more interesting facts of the boys from Hamburg.<br /><br />  Overall, this is the best thing that happened to metal since the 1995 re-masters of the Iron Maiden collection (1998 remasters good, but not all the goodie tracks).  I wouldn't even hesitate to say this is more a important remasters series for metal of this genre, because it give helloween to re-gain the international recognition it should have again.  The Walls Of Jericho are the best place to see the origins of one of Germany's best exports.
B000FFJ85I|3.0|A.F.I. used to be a lot better (I say that for all those new fans who didn't know about them until this album came out) back when they still played as a old school punk-revival band, complete with excellent bass lines and somewhat above-average drumming, but after I listened to this album, disappointment filled my ears. 2000's \\"The Art of Drowning\\" was such an excellent, refreshing album that brought some variety to the worn-out pop-punk scene and I hoped that they would continue to make albums of that level, but the release of 2003's \\"Sing the Sorrow\\" marked a turning point in the direction of the band's music, and it saddened me. I was sorely disappointed when I watched the video for \\"Silver and Cold\\" and saw that they had abandoned their fast, punky sound for a slower, more poppy sound. Worse yet, lead singer Davey Havok's voice sounded even more feminine than ever before, sounding almost cheesy as he reached for those high notes. The album overall wasn't too bad, but replay value was significantly lower. Worse yet, they gave in to the pressures of their label and started playing the overdone mainstream rock style, leading to this piece of mediocre musicianship.<br /><br />Davey's voice has gotten a little lower-pitched since the last album, but it is now less recognizable and is interchangeable with other similar bands. It's somewhat tolerable, but after a couple of songs it starts to get annoying and detracts from the natural beauty of the music and ruining what could be otherwise enjoyable songs. He also thought it would be a good idea to try screaming, but being a devoted metalhead and knowing a thing or two about screaming and growling, the screaming does nothing for me and sounds more like filler than anything to help the song; in all honesty, it sounds like Davey is hurting his voice. Guitarist Jade Puget plays cliched soft lines seen in almost every other band along these lines and strumming American riffs that don't give the album much thickness, which the guitar is supposed to do. The guitars are the most important part of any rock album, and there is little progression or impressive skill to be found in his musicianship. Bassist Hunter Burgan isn't nearly as good as he used to be, giving up his driving bass lines like those displayed in \\"The Art of Drowning\\" for a softer, simpler sound that does fit better with the music, but it's not my cup of tea. And of all the members, the biggest disappointment is the drumming provided by Adam Carson, which is boring, and simplistic. He once played compelling drum riffs and speedy pseudo-blast beats, but now he's just there to give the music a beat and little else.<br /><br />Bottom line: A.F.I. has much more potential than this, but they have proven to all of their fans that they're only interested in playing music that will reach the largest audience instead of sticking with their winning punk-revival formula. You can still listen them if you wish to, but A.F.I. has turned themselves into sell-outs like many others before them. As long as I have their classic works I don't give a damn where they go with their music, but I'll miss being able to buy one of their albums and have it be filled with compelling songs.<br /><br />5/10r is supposed to do. The guitars are the most important part of any rock album, and there is little progression or impressive skill to be found in his musicianship. Bassist Hunter Burgan isn't nearly as good as he used to be, giving up his driving bass lines like those displayed in \\"The Art of Drowning\\" for a softer, simpler sound that does fit better with the music, but it's not my cup of tea. And of all the members, the biggest disappointment is the drumming provided by Adam Carson, which is boring, and simplistic. He once played compelling drum riffs and speedy pseudo-blast beats, but now he's just there to give the music a beat and little else.    Bottom line: A.F.I. has much more potential than this, but they have proven to all of their fans that they're only interested in playing music that will reach the largest audience instead of sticking with their winning punk-revival formula. You can still listen them if you wish to, but A.F.I. has turned themselves into sell-outs like many others before them. As long as I have their classic works I don't give a damn where they go with their music, but I'll miss being able to buy one of their albums and have it be filled with compelling songs.    5/10
B000EOTEPO|5.0|Now, I already reviewed the first version of this album, and being that it is in my top 5 favorite albums of all time, I figured I might as well add my review to the re-release. Also,don't mind the amazon review, that is for their first album released many years before this one.<br /><br />Few albums come along in ones life where the music leaves you so speechless. For me, this is one of them. This is not only Immortal's best work in general but one of the greatest Black Metal albums ever to be released. Nothing can top Abbath's brutal riffs and his throat ripping vocals. The atmosphere of Darkthrone is here and the talent of Emperor. However, between all that makes this cd a masterpiece is some true beauty. Such as the main riff in Solarfall and the intro in At the Heart of Winter for a few examples. This is a true masterpiece of winter beauty and winter carnage.<br /><br />1. Withstand the Fall of Time (8:29) The first track begins with a single riff before the rest joins in, while the riff not really memorable will grow on you. The first minute is spent gearing up before the song gets into full speed. About 3 and a half minutes into the song it slows down before getting a second wind about 4:15 into it and doesn't stop until the song quietly dies out. WOnderful opening track. I could not think of a better song to open up this album. 4.5/5<br /><br />2. Solarfall (6:02) Immortal's best song of all time. A short drum roll falls in follwoed by one of my favorite riffs of all time then hell is broken loose upon an unsuspecting listener. The song does not let up for one second and has some of their best drumming as well. The vocals are enough to make you wish to conquer all you face. The vocals are almost dreadfully slow in a good way, almost like you wonder how he isn't tearing all of his vocal chords. The song slows down 2:20 into it with some slow drumming but soon returns with that crushing riff. Best song here. 25/5<br /><br />3. Tragedies Blows At Horizon (8:55) This song is 8 minutes and 55 seconds of pure magic. It really starts up about 40 seconds into it and grabs you with hardened claws and refuses to let up. I love the way the guitar riff kicks in at 4:30 with nothing but a take no prisoners attitude. A real highlight on the album. 5/5<br /><br />4. Where Dark and Light Don't Differ (6:45) The first song I heard on this album and it is a winner. The most thrash influenced track on this album has no mellow intro but just decides to come at you full force. The best drumming on the album appears here. The riff that kicks in at 1 minute is majestic and incredible. An epic track. 10/5<br /><br />5. At the Heart of Winter (8:00) This song honestly makes you feel like you're walking into the front line of a war at the heart of a winter storm. This song runs on talent, emotion and an epic battle cry. The two minute intro can't even prepare you for what is to come. Then the rest of the song kicks in barreling down on you like an avalanche you know you can't escape. With guitar playing that just screams talent. The rest of the song continues the epic trail the first half of the song left us with. 20/5<br /><br />6. Years of Silent Sorrow (7:53) Well, instead of ending this masterpiece on a quiet note. Abbath and crew decide to go out fighting. With one of the fastest songs on the album begins the drums tear through your ears. The guitar is pretty fast in an almost frantic fashion at certain times. \\"Dome in the sky black winds to taste<br /><br />shadowed spirits lead my way...<br /><br />Drifting everly alone years of silent sorrow<br /><br />until I'm home... \\" With those words spoken the final song dies out leaving you only time to pick yourself up and try to comprehend the incredible album you just heard. 5/5<br /><br />In conclusion, if you haven't stopped reading this yet and purchased this album. I recommend you do so right now. Enjoy.izon (8:55) This song is 8 minutes and 55 seconds of pure magic. It really starts up about 40 seconds into it and grabs you with hardened claws and refuses to let up. I love the way the guitar riff kicks in at 4:30 with nothing but a take no prisoners attitude. 630522885X|5.0|The dvd's in the proper CinemaScope ratio, but is non-anamorphic. With that in mind, the picture quality's great.     The movie's among the most beautiful I've seen. As a painter and former animator, I've seen many and am a tough critic. It seems to me, director Max Ophuls and crew were among the few working in the '50s who really understood how to compose in widescreen; in fact, this was Max's only widescreen movie and yet he was a master at it.     Few people complain that old master paintings have yellowed or been cropped, or that the Van Gogh's have turned green, but if a movie looks like it was made ten years ago, rather than today, people complain. This movie's fifty years old, but it doesn't at all look like it, which is remarkable considering it was shot in Eastmancolor, which unlike Technicolor, an old animator I worked under once told me, is very unstable. (Apparently Technicolor release prints exist.)    The Germans recently put a lot of time and money into honoring the director's intentions by constructing (as close as possible) the original, intended version (longer running time, etc.), but the director's son, Marcel, stopped it from being shown (supposedly because in the restored version some of the characters don't/don't always speak French; note, they were never intended to.) This dvd allows us to experience the next best thing. In the (unavailable) German, the colors are supposedly even better, but the colors in this version/dvd are still stunning. You probably know, but just in case: in non-digital media, colors age and in all likelihood different colors age differently. Fortunately no hacks have gone in on this dvd with automatic software and cranked up the colors incorrectly. I used to be troubled that the picture on this dvd is slightly (and I do mean SLIGHTLY) off center; one side is cropped just a sliver. But recently I learned it's not distributor Fox Lorber's fault. The cropping was done years ago by hacks re-doing the soundtrack. What wouldpeople have the distributor do, chop off a sliver on the opposite side to match? Crank up the already bright, beautiful colors into oversaturated kitsch?     If you want to see \\"Lola Montes,\\" grab this dvd.     Watching \\"Lola Montes\\" is a bit like watching Ingres' \\"Grand Odalisque\\" come to life.
