B000ETQRCM|3.0|I have mixed emotions about this recording. It's enjoyable to me that the band is going back to the hard-edged approach that brought them recognition, but perhaps time has taken a toll. The recording is mushy and indistinct (the blame for that can most likely be placed at the feet of the engineer), but additionally the playing sounds a bit sloppy and lackluster and Eddie frankly seems to be having a bit of trouble singing to pitch. The guitar tone is horrid, as if a bargain-bin mike was set up in the far corner of a garage with a cheesy amp as a source. Still, though, some of the magic is still there. I have respect for what these guys have done, and I found myself enjoying simply hearing them again.

B000FFJ85I|3.0|...if you are expecting AFI to cut back to their roots and pretend as if Sing the Sorrow was never released stay away from this album for the progression only goes deeper. On the other hand looking at it from a long-time AFI fan I give this 2 stars (hence the average of 3 stars) because I (and I don't think I stand alone when saying this) just miss the old AFI; the fast, crude, thrashy punk band that I knew for so long. B000F3A7LE|5.0|In this March to 1981, harnessing the three disciplines, Robert Fripp drew what can, in one context, be viewed as a blueprint for where he, and his participation in Crimson, were headed in the march toward 1981, which would see Crim emerge as a very different beast. (well, all Crims are different, but the Fripp-Belew-Bruford-Levin quartet was something else altogether). I don't believe you can fully appreciate this effort without listening to the interview from Atlanta that is available as a download on DGM Live. <br />A lot of water had flowed very rapidly under Robert's bridge in the mid-70's and finding himself in NYC at a very creative time, even by NYC standards, Fripp seemed to be at the nerve center through most of it. In a very short sequence he had been involved with both of Gabriel's first two records, The Roches remarkable KEEP ON DOING (espousing, as he did with PG2, his concept of Audio Verite), Talking Heads' FEAR OF MUSIC, sessions with Eno, Bowie and a host of others on the avant-rock/pop scene. All of this seemed to galvanize him as a creative artist. Juices flowing, he brought colleagues in to craft an album unlike anything anyone had imagined doing to that point. This is often hailed as the SGT. PEPPER of the avant-garde, and without putting too precious a point on it, the record is all that and more. <br />What's on offer here is both the aborted efforted in which Tommy Mattola, before unleashing Maraih Carey on the world, was already generating abominations by ripping the vocal tracks Darryl Hall laid down from this record and then forbidding Hall to release his own solo shot as produced by Fripp. A second disc restores Hall's contributions and by comparison, shows just how heroic Pete Hamill was in putting the first effort together in the face of the abominable future shlub of the equally grating Carey. <br />As to the merits of the disc itself, the sonic upgrade is not just phenomenal (you expect that from Fripp) but it's a thing of wonder andit gives you a sense of just how much focus it took to have a singer, a guitarist, a bass player perform in three different time signatures with an ambient frippertronics, found sounds and a whole lot of passion drive the title track. Herein you'll likely here the germination of songs like \\"Matte Kudasai\\". Fripp has labelled \\"Breathless\\" as extraordinarily difficult, yet emminently listenable. It is a kindred spirit to various Larks, Fractures and Vrooms that preceded and would follow this track, and this without Bruford! Jerry Marotta is more than up to the tasks at hand. Fripp's allegiance with Tony Levin was initially forged through PG1, but here Levin is let loose and the seeds for the next arising of the Crimson King are audibly taking root, nourishment and growth through this incendiary recording. <br />Terre Roche, Darryl Hall and Pete Hamill offer an entirely new approach to crafting lyrics to the polyrhythmic galeforce of Fripp's music combined with lyrics from Joanna Walton and Hall himself. Fripp's mother and his mentor, J G Bennett contribute conversation, as does a family in Hell's Kitchen who are arguing with their daughter as Fripp takes NYNYNY to a place even NYers might not imagine. And all ofthe thunder, fury and passion are washed away before the final comments of Bennett and Peter Gabriel's lovely solo take with Frippertronics on \\"Here Comes The Flood.\\" There is a wry comment from Eno to close out the disc. This is an extraordinary effort. <br />But I insist that you should download the interview from DGM Live. An attentive interviewer presents Fripp with a platform to enegage the audience in athoughtful consideration of what is on offer, and manages a few \\"bruning questions\\" of her own that are enlightening in their prodding of the King's Prime Minister. Fripp speaks of what is \\"appropriate\\", especially with regard to \\"Here Comes the Flood.\\" I am reminded of nothing so much as Heidegger's investigations, especially of the greek origin of \\"appropriation.\\" I have no idea if Fripp is aware of the investigations, but he comes as close to Heidgger as anyone I have ever heard speak in taking apart what it is that is the business of Musicking, much as Martin set about on his path to clear the ground for Thinking. Coupled with the reference points to the recordings, this is as profound an inetrview as I have heard Fripp deliver. <br />And the interview concludes with Fripp's extrapolation of Discotronics in 5/8 based on the pulse of the interviewer's heart. Amazing.

Enter a world where you have to fill out a form to get a form to fill out...in triplicate. Big government where the left hand doesn't know the right hand exists... <br /> <br />San Lowry is a bureaucrat-drone with a tiny automated apartment, a distant mother who enjoys recreational plastic surgery and a never-ending flow of paper to push around the desk he shares --through a wall--with another bureaucrat. You have to see it to believe it. Sam adds some exitement to his humdrum life by imagining fantastic light-infused scenes starring a winged hero--perhaps human potential, his own evaporating opportunities as he ages, or...perhaps someone he has met. <br /> <br />While going through the efforts to correct a simple mistake which apparently cost a meek family man his life, Sam rubs elbows with a skillful cultural terrorist who delights in sticking it to the system. It doesn't take long for Sam to become mixed up in events he's really not too sure about. Throughout he seems an average guy who can't really figure out whether he's here or there, and through attempting to make right for his bureaucracy, becomes a victim of it. But a least he finds love too! <br /> <br />This is not a simple clean tale with an easy ending, you do have to think. Worth seeing for the lavish imagination scenes alone. Dry humor meets absurdity. Welcome to Sam Lowry's world. <br /> <br />

B00006AW2L|5.0|I know that the Stones started in 1963 but this is where they really get good. Next comes Under My Thumb with its marimba sound that creates a unavoidable groove. I'll admit that it's grown on me since I first heard it where I hated it.  All in all, good album but I agree with the review who recommended Flowers over this one.  With Flowers, you get Lady Jane, the highlight of the album plus Let's Spend The Night Together, Ruby Tuesday, and much much more.
0679409920|4.0|Published in 1978, this novel comes relatively late in Greene's career, and indeed at the beginning it has a warmly old-fashioned air: the London clubs and country shooting parties of the establishment figures, the pub lunches and middle-class suburban life of the civil servants. Everything seems downplayed; the branch of the secret services where this is set deals merely with routine reports out of Africa, not with the major players in the Cold War. There have been leaks, and the reader gradually becomes aware of who is behind them. But, as the title suggests, Greene's interest is in human factors such as love, gratitude, the ties of family, and the consolation of routine; grand political concerns seem of little account. But political matters intervene wily-nily, leading to an ending that is as bleak as it is inevitable.<br /><br />Earlier in his career, Greene used to separate his thrillers from his more serious novels, calling them \\"entertainments.\\" He had dropped the distinction by this point, but the first half of the book at least falls very much in the \\"entertainment\\" vein, rather as though Greene were an older relative of John Le Carr&eacute;. Later, as the portrayal of the characters at center stage vie for the reader's interest with the many-layers of backstage manipulation, the book gains true novelistic depth. But I was disappointed that Greene did take this as far as in his earlier works. Although his protagonist is tormented by his situation, one never has any doubts that he is doing the right thing; his crisis of conscience is small compared to that of, say, the leading figure in [[ASIN:0143039024 THE QUIET AMERICAN]]. Greene toys briefly with one of his favorite themes, the Catholic view of sin and redemption through confession, but unlike, say, [[ASIN:0099478420 THE HEART OF THE MATTER]] or [[ASIN:0099478471 BRIGHTON ROCK]], where the issue is central, the equivalent episode here is brushed away almost cynically. And his characters are almost too black and white; although there is a suggestion of a nuanced conscience in at least two of them (Sir John Hargreaves and Colonel Daintry), ultimately this is allowed to count for very little in the outcome of the story.<br /><br />I realize that the preceding paragraph has been largely negative. I like Greene immensely for his uncanny ability to evoke atmosphere, especially in social terms. I admire his ability to draw one into the lives, the souls, of his characters. And I greatly respect his moral integrity. It is high praise to be able to write about the book in these terms at all. I would just have preferred the moral issues to have been resolved as a transcendent victory or even as tragedy, rather than as the bleak outcome of some slightly sordid comedy, no matter how realistic that may be.although there is a suggestion of a nuanced conscience in at least two of them (Sir John Hargreaves and Colonel Daintry), ultimately this is allowed to count for very little in the outcome of the story.    I realize that the preceding paragraph has been largely negative. I like Greene immensely for his uncanny ability to evoke atmosphere, especially in social terms. I admire his ability to draw one into the lives, the souls, of his characters. And I greatly respect his moral integrity. It is high praise to be able to write about the book in these terms at all. I would just have preferred the moral issues to have been resolved as a transcendent victory or even as tragedy, rather than as the bleak outcome of some slightly sordid comedy, no matter how realistic that may be.

B0002S94OS|5.0|This album very well may be the best I've ever heard. Of course, I have said this before, but this time, I'm going to stick to my guns. Ashes of the Wake has everything. Let's begin with how this band came to be. Formerly known as Burn the Priest, Lamb of God consisted of only four members, Abe Spear being the guitarist rather than Mark Morton. Soon thereafter, Morton returned from Chicago to replace Abe as the guitarist. Meanwhile, the band had added another guitarist to the band, brother to drummer, Chris Adler, Will Adler. The aforementioned three, vocalist, Randy Blithe, and bassist, John Campbell, began to rise up from the underground Virginian metal scene and become what they are today, a force to be reckoned with. As far as the CD goes, it is a non-stop, riff-packed, double bass drumming thing of beauty. Randy grumbles and howls flawlessly on every track. The whole CD is a highlight, but here are some of my top favorites :    1. Laid To Rest - The album's first single, however, the video was kind of a disappointment. The beginning of the song is spoken by Randy, normally I wouldn't like that but for this song it really fits it well. What makes the song so great is the strong riff on the verses. The chorus is almost similar to a shout-along rather than a growl, which is another neat plus.  5. Omerta - This song also begins with a spoken portion, but even though it makes you think, I didn't find it necessary. That's just my opinion. Throughout the song, it seems as if Randy's voice has an echo effect on it, which is pretty cool. My favorite part of the song is around the break when only the drums and guitar are audible. All of the sudden, there is a sweet lead in by Chris and a tempo change.  6. Blood Of The Scribe - This song is chock-full of very high-pitched, almost emo-like, yelps. What really makes the song, for me, is the sixtuplet double kicking layed down by Chris on several occasions.  10. Ashes Of The Wake - The title track has no vocals, but ironically is my absolute favorite of the CD. When I first heard the song, I'd swear I listened to it about 10 times. The five guitar solos, done by guest guitarists Chris Poland and Alex Skolnick, are what make this track one of my favorites out there. The transition riffs and solid drumming also make this song sound awesome.    The only flaw I can really find with this album is that the bass is not powerful enough. Although it may be audible, I hope that on Sacrament, Lamb of God's new album, in stores August 22, the bass is more powerful and able to carry the band. Overall, if you're into metal, in fact, even if you're not into metal, you NEED this album, because this is an album that we will be talking about 10 years from now. Thank you for your time.

B00005ONMP|3.0|First, the good: Great box design for packaging, great booklet in various languages describing the history of all the performed works, great value for money, excellent representation of the great Mendelssohn's best works.<br /><br />Now, the bad: the problem with compilations like this is that the material tends to have been recorded at different times and places and frequently by different personnel on various recording equipment of varying quality.  What this means is that some tracks within each disc sound much better then others and even whole discs come in varying sound qualities.<br /><br />Fortunately, the best disc, disc one starts out very well with the great first symphony and ends with the composer's best Overtures and the quality of the sound recording is very good.  Then we get to disc 2 and the sound quality can only be described as abysmal.  The difference in the sound is like night and day when compared with the first disc.  The third disc sounds much better but is still not as good as the first disc while the last disc comes somewhere in between the second and third.<br /><br />There's no doubting the quality of the performances though by Claudio Abbado and the LSO and of course the choice of material but too bad about the inconsistency of the sound quality from track to track and from disc to disc.<br /><br />Still, the 3 stars are for the good points listed above and for the great disc 1.

Then again, I was about twelve. <br /> <br />It is several years later and I am still in love with the prince. Having read the book more times than I care to recount, it was only last year that I realized de Saint-Exupery was saying something deeper about love and the world. <br /> <br />Throughout, the book is quite cynical of the \\"grown-ups\\", its target audience being children -- or grown-ups who are still like children, like the narrator. <br /> <br />Though it seems like a short book it should certainly be reread a few times to grasp the beautiful prose and the second meaning hidden behind the prince and his rose and the stars. The ending is beautiful and sad, and might cause tears to those with tenderer hearts. <br /> <br />A fantastic book, ranking with Peter S. Beagle's wonderful \\"The Last Unicorn,\\" in my opinion. <br /> <br />But -- get the Woods translation.
B000EGCITG|4.0|It may not have been as large a hit as her 2001 triumph \\"M!ssundaztood,\\" but P!nk's 2003 LP \\"Try This\\" certified her artistic prowess and left no doubt that she was in a class all her own. She continues this trend of increasing musical quirkiness and thus quality with her aptly-titled comeback effort \\"I'm Not Dead.\\"<br /><br />With lead single \\"Stupid Girls\\" P!nk has affirmed in a downright infectious way what many have felt in frustration for the longest time - this culture cultivates stupid girls, and everything about it is despicable. Also, follow-up single \\"Who Knew?,\\" on which she collaborated with pop tunesmith Max Martin, shines and sparkles in all the right places and is a likely summer hit.<br /><br />However, sharp material abounds in much variety on \\"I'm Not Dead.\\" The title crack crackles and lilts with forthrightness amid its raw arrangements and stream-of-conscious lyrics, while \\"Dear Mr. President,\\" collaboration with the Indigo Girls, may be the most dignified and effective protest of the Bush administration recorded yet.<br /><br />\\"How do you sleep while the rest of us cry?/How do you dream when a mother has no chance to say goodbye?/How do you walk with your head held high?/Can you even look me in the eye?\\"<br /><br />She also includes an excellent slice of pure power pop with \\"Leave Me Alone (I'm Lonely)\\" that fits her personal style while still sounding pointedly mainstream, while brooding over intense subject matter in selections like the passionate \\"Long Way to Happy\\" and \\"Runaway,\\" the latter of which serves as a companion to \\"Conversations With My 13-Year-Old Self.\\" Both realistically articulate the darkness that often accompanies growing up, a skill P!nk has proven deft at.<br /><br />Also included are the illustrious \\"Nobody Knows\\" and \\"The One That Got Away,\\" the latter of which finds her sounding like a much more talented Phoebe Buffay. Last but not least, she displays her signature attitude with \\"`Cuz I Can\\" and \\"U + Ur Hand,\\" the latter in which she forthrightly tells her man that she refuses to be objectified as a sex object.<br /><br />Overall, P!nk has come a long way since the pop/r&b trappings of her debut album six years ago. Not only has her music increased in quality with each successive record, but she has proven herself an excellent role model for young people through her lyrics, individuality and political awareness. Pop stars may be a dime a dozen these days, but she is an exception to the rule.and,\\" the latter in which she forthrightly tells her man that she refuses to be objectified as a sex object.  <br /> <br />Overall, P!nk has come a long way since the pop/r&b trappings of her debut album six years ago. B000002UJQ|5.0|I used to be a massive Radiohead fan, but then drifted away, and now, just after loading OK Computer on my IPod, and listening to in it's entirety for the first time in a long time, it blows my mind just as much as ever.  <br /> <br />For me, I think this whole cd is about loneliness and isolation in the modern technology driven world, and in the future. This is just a small interpretation of the music and themse here. You could probably dig through this album and fuel an entire thesis on what's here. While this thought may turn off some people from this album, just look at it this way, the more challenging it is, the lesser the chance of you getting tired of it. And let me tell you, I've had this cd for four years, and I still come back to it again and again. It's the most haunting listen of the 90s in my opinion. <br /> <br />Musically, OK Computer sounds like nothing else. It's rock mixed with electronica, mixed with ambience and psychedelia, and given a cold, blurry production. Not surprisingly, this cd goes best on a winter's day when it is all white outside and the snow is falling. The best examples would probably be \\"Airbag\\" with the jingle bells in the background, \\"Subteranian Homesick Alien\\" with it's shimmering foggy textures, and my personal favorite \\"The Tourist\\" with it's at once calm, yet epic multi-layered textures. The only song that recalls The Bends here is \\"Electioneering\\", a garage-band song that still manages to be ambient.  <br /> <br />Thom Yorke is in full Springsteen mode here with his dozen stories of everyday people existing in this cold and mechanical future, and their outlook on it. New-found hope for life is expressed by the character who is saved in a car-crash by an airbag in the song \\"Airbag\\". Paranoia in \\"Subterranian Homesick Blues\\" and \\"Karma Police\\", and resolve in \\"The Tourist\\".  <br /> <br />This disc is unlike anything you're likely to hear again for a long long time, and it's possibly the best artistic reflection of what society is spiraling steadily towards in pop culture today. This cd for me is a landmark because it is an unforgivingly honest and effective look at pop-culture and society today. If you're in it just for the music, it is one hell of a ride that you will never get bored of.

1594200823|5.0|I agree with many of the other reviewers here, the book is eye-opening and paradigm transforming. Perhaps it is not as even-handed or skeptical a view as it could have been. I enjoyed the middle section of the book concerning Joel Salatin's Polyface farm like many other readers. I also like the section before that which discussed much of the context and history that led into the organic food movement, starting in the 1940's when man-made petro based fertilizers first came into use through the 60's communal farm movement and finally to the 90's organic food boom to today. 0312983867|4.0|Evelyn Soder and her daughter Annie are missing. Mabel Markowitz, the neighbor of Stephanie Plum's parents, is Evelyn's grandmother, and she's desperate to find out what happened to her family. As a favor to her parents and Mabel, taking only a slice (or twelve) of coffee cake as payment, Stephanie agrees to do some investigating into Evelyn's whereabouts.  But she's not the only one looking for the missing mother and daughter. Evelyn's ex-husband, Steven, has hired Jeanne Ellen Burrows--a.k.a. \\"the female Ranger\\"--to track down his wife and daughter, and scary Eddie Abruzzi, who owns both the property where Evelyn lives and Steven's bar, is also on the trail.     Then Stephanie finds herself being tailed by a man in a rabbit suit (probably she never should have told Abruzzi she liked bunnies); her car is blown up (again); and her apartment is infested with creepy crawlies (including snakes, tarantulas, and a dead guy on her couch). Deciding she's taken on more than she can handle, she calls in the reinforcements: Ranger, who used to be Special Forces but now does many things (driving Stephanie wild with desire included), and her on-again, off-again boyfriend Joe Morelli.  And don't worry, the rest of the crew is in on the action, too, including ex-ho Lula, who's just bought herself a bright yellow mini-skirt and dyed her hair to match it. There's even a new \\"Kloughn\\" in town (NOT c-l-o-w-n), a correspondence-course lawyer who's set on wooing Steph's sister, Valerie.  And we readers definitely learn one thing in HARD EIGHT:  Don't mess with Mama Plum's little girl!    Other reviewers here are right:  Stephanie's character takes a major hit in HARD EIGHT.  It's not like Stephanie to have to rely on a man to keep her safe, but that's all she does this time out (although I'd probably call on Ranger or Morelli myself--but not necessarily for protection). Although the novel is characteristically funny, this time much of the humor is at Stephanie's expense; it sometimes feels like we're laughing at her rather than with her: \\"Oh, she lost another pair of handcuffs\\" or \\"Ha ha, she's being attacked by geese because she was dumb enough to throw a Cracker Jack at one.\\"  I want gutsy, slightly-ditzy-but-not-dumb Stephanie back!    But I still can't give HARD EIGHT less than four stars. It was roaringly funny, just as we \\"Plummers\\" have come to expect (one scene, in particular, involving a bagel shop, Grandma Mazur, Bill Clinton, and a bunny performing an extremely lewd act made me laugh so hard I nearly cried).  And for all you Ranger fans out there, we (and Stephanie) get to know him a LOT better in HARD EIGHT (hint: the title of this novel may be more appropriate than you think).     Evanovich has no competition when it comes to balancing outrageous characters and outlandish situations with cold, gritty suspense; there's no one else in crime fiction who writes like she can.  I always try to read the Stephanie Plum books after I've just finished reading someting pretty heavy, which makes the characters and the humor even sweeter to return to.  It's so wonderful to come back to the Burg. I never know what I'm going to find--but it's always even funnier than I expect.

Corbin Bernsen, who has been in some really bad films in the past few years, redeems himself playing the nasty villain of the piece.  I really enjoyed this movie; it's so much fun and is one of the best I've seen this year.  HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.

B00006LJ6X|4.0|Chicago VII is the first album to present songs written by every one of the members.  Each member stretches a little, too, sometimes bringing in his own session musicians, hence my tag of \\"White Album\\".  It is because you see the individuality of every member, and not so much the pure full ensemble found in the first six albums, that this album is so well-liked and fresh.  It is still Chicago, but there are some differences and trends.<br /><br />First - Peter Cetera is the primary lead singer for the first time.  Three of them are ballads that did well in the charts.  One is a ballad without any horns, foreshadowing his solo career.<br /><br />Second - Chicago is clearly well into their latin period now.  Laudir de Oliveira is a real presence on this album, while not being listed as a member yet.  Their raw rock sound of CTA - VI is diminished, but the latin era is here, and a lot of people love it.<br /><br />Third - Lee Loughnane's raspy  first lead vocal and his voice added prominently to the backgrounds on several tracks is a sort of look ahead to the vocal sounds of the Champlin era.<br /><br />Fourth - The only song to feature only The Original Seven on it is \\"Women Don't Want To Love Me\\" - the weakest track on the entire album.<br /><br />Fifth - Robert Lamm is beginning to hand over the creative reigns.  His time is split between this album and his first solo album - for which several very good songs that could have been pitched to Chicago are recorded.  He is not the creative monster he had been in prior albums.<br /><br />This was the first Chicago album I bought after becoming a fan in 1973.  I anticipated it for months.  I bought it the first day it appeared in the stores, and when I played it I remember that a number of things disappointed me - I didn't like the congas, the strings, the extra singers and instrumentalists.  There weren't enough horns and extended solos.  I listened to the entire album, hoping with each track that one of the songs would be like Make Me Smile, or Now That You're Gone.  It never happened.<br /><br />As I have grown older, I have come to love it.  It is Chicago's only true epic album, not just because it was a double, but because it sprawls all over the musical landscape.  To me - they are no longer a \\"Chicago\\" band, but more of a west coast band with this album.  Their skill at making records shows.  It is indeed their last experimental album.  After this, you will hear a lot more fun and maturity in their product.<br /><br />32 years later - I listen to it now and appreciate it more than ever.  I even like \\"Women Don't Want To Love Me\\".  It is the last track on any album to have only The Original Seven.  Listen to the relentless instrumental breaks.  Yeah, this song makes it.  It is a fitting farewell to the groundbreaking style that burst upon the scene in 1970.<br /><br />But an epic is not necessarily a five-star.  That is reserved only for Chicago's very best albums.  This is an excellent album, but not one of the best.  I recommend it for every music fan, not just fans of Chicago.e songs would be like Make Me Smile, or Now That You're Gone.  It never happened. <br /> <br />As I have grown older, I have come to love it.  It is Chicago's only true epic album, not just because it was a double, but because it sprawls all over the musical landscape.  To me - they are no longer a \\"Chicago\\" band, but more of a west coast band with this album.  Their skill at making records shows.  It is indeed their last experimental album.  After this, you will hear a lot more fun and maturity in their product.  <br /> <br />32 years later - I listen to it now and appreciate it more than ever.  I even like \\"Women Don't Want To Love Me\\".  It is the last track on any album to have only The Original Seven.  Listen to the relentless instrumental breaks.   Yeah, this song makes it.  It is a fitting farewell to the groundbreaking style that burst upon the scene in 1970. <br /> <br />But an epic is not necessarily a five-star.  That is reserved only for Chicago's very best albums.  This is an excellent album, but not one of the best.  I recommend it for every music fan, not just fans of Chicago.

0224076051|4.0|I haven't read the book (yet), but I have followed Peter Woit's blog for the better part of a year on a regular basis, so I have a pretty good idea about what the book covers.  I have also, from time to time, attempted to read Lubos Motl's blog as well.  Lubos has also reviewed Peter's book here--in highly negative terms.  All I can say is don't take Lubos's seriously without checking Lubos's blog yourself; as smart as he might be, he occupies a unique, alternate universe with regard to the conventions of civilized discourse.   <br /> <br />The math involved is far too abstuse for me to form a judgement on the core issues of string theory itself.  Instead, I wish to make a point about Peter's philosophical stance: he's far too quick to wish that theoretical physics would continue to make testable predictions.  In the golden years (by which I refer to the years leading up to the formation of the standard model) that was indeed how physics worked.  It's no longer clear to me that physics *can* return to that idealized modus operandi.  I never felt reading Peter's blog that he pondered that possibility deeply enough.   <br /> <br />There's a major distinction to be drawn here between a theory that can't be tested in principle, and a theory we simply can't *afford* to test, considering the cost of the equipment required (a supercollider the size of the solar system would be a good start in stocking any modern experimental physics lab).   <br /> <br />What Peter points out abundantly well is that the nature of the game has changed: the experimental checks and balances that existed a generation ago are presently in a state of shambles.  Part of the problem here lies with the standard model itself: it is simply too good already.  We are mostly seeking to augment the standard model on theoretical grounds, not practical grounds.  If the standard model were failing on practical grounds, there would be no shortage of testable remedies proposed.   <br /> <br />The elephant in the room, as far as I'm concerned, is the question of just how much is there left to predict that can be measured/tested by machines we can reasonably afford to build/operate.  The string theorists would like us to believe that we fund their activities because they are on the scent of another set of discoveries as momentus as the standard model itself.  This is quite simply not going to transpire.  Even in the best case scenario where a predictive theory emerges, the vast majority of what it predicts will remain outside of experimental reach; the best we can hope for is a few tantalising glimmers of experimental corroboration, whereas the standard model was far more broadly corroborated during its formative years than we can ever hope to replicate concerning its ultimate successor.     <br /> <br />The philosophical question this raises is this: why does society continue to support the theoretical physics enterprise when it has long become clear that future successes--whatever form they might take--will not resemble any template of past success?  Much of the core of Peter's book is that the general public as yet fails to understand that this is the proposition we face.   <br /> <br />Unlike Peter, I'm prepared to accept that wrangling string theory into a testable configuration is not a twenty-year task; it could well be a one-hundred year task.  It is my belief that the future of physics will increasingly consist of long hopeless voyages into the theoretical weeds; the physical world no longer speaks to us in the price range we can afford to stump up.  I have no problem with society continuing to support speculative theory.  I accept that very few or no testable propositions might emerge over many generations of work.  Experimental validation was a tremendous luxury while it lasted.  The next forty orders of magnitude in the energy scale won't give up their secrets half so readily as we fondly recall.   <br /> <br />The difficulty this brings about--and here I am entirely with Peter again--is that past standards for deciding which working physicists were making positive contributions and which physicists are publishing rubish have gone far by the board.  We now have this giant abstruse literature which contains large amounts of pure rublish (of that I harbour no doubt whatsoever), yet there is presently no viable frame of reference for determining which 50% (or 90%, or 99%) is the rubish, and what remaining fragment is worth keeping.  The string theorists cite each other, no outside party understands anything, it has all become highly cabalistic.  Lubos, in particular, loves to point out how the outside parties lack the IQ points to appreciate this beautiful theory.  That might well be the case, but it is *not* the case in the animal kingdom that the low-IQ outsiders continue to indefinitely foot the bill because the high-IQ insiders ooh and aah ever so persuasively; Lubos should be careful what he wishes for.   <br /> <br />If string theory is to become an intellectual venture of many hundred years, and it might take that long to get anywhere, why are we pouring so much money and talent into it now, in this generation?  There are other areas of physics that might have more immediate promise.  With every new discovery in string theory, it only seems that the weeds become that much taller and thicker.  How many people are left who believe that string theory is primed to burst out into the sunlight with an experimental prediction any day now?  Not many, that I can see.   <br /> <br />Like Peter, the landscape is what really gets my goat.  To my ear the landscape is quasi-religous speculation.  I'm not opposed to people speculating about the landscape, nor am I opposed to departments of religious studies.  I am, however, strongly opposed to the use of funds earmarked for physics being put to this purpose; such work belongs in a department explicitly organised to recognize and promote expertise in quasi-religious speculation.  Physics has no such tradition, and I sincerely hope it never does.   <br /> <br />Peter is great in promoting the case that string theorists have deviated far from the historical norms of physics as a discipline.  He isn't so good at confronting the philosophical question of whether historical physics (the semi-lockstep march of theory and experiment that we so fondly recall) continues to exist in any practical sense.  If it doesn't, string theory might be the best we can do.  However--if that is the case--there's a lot to be said for the general public (who ultimately foot the bill) understanding that this sea change has indeed taken place, and in that cause I regard Peter's contributions to the public debate as an excellent first step.
B000BVQ9JO|4.0|I've been a strokes fan for a while and I can say safley that this record is solid. 6305263248|3.0|*WARNING* Review full of SPOILERS<br /><br />A masterless samurai? I suppose if Samurai had a complete and utter disregard for human life, maybe the premise of the move works. Maybe Ronin roamed the countryside randomly attacking their enemies and killing any number of innocent civilians who were just in the way. If they did, then De Niro as a modern Ronin is quite believable.<br /><br />De Niro is a talented actor, and Jean Reno does a great job as his partner in crime. The supporting cast all play their roles excellently. If I was judging the movie on acting alone, it would get five stars.<br /><br />The plot of the movie frustrated me. In the real world, there are no such people as these characters. If a group of such competent criminals existed in the world, they would rule us all. De Niro's incredible driving skill, shooting skill and ability to calmly direct crude surgery on his own body without the benefit of local anesthetic were all a little over the top.<br /><br />Here's the thing - you can't just run around Europe getting into random gun battles and killing multiple people the way the crew in Ronin does. The amount of random violence between pursuer and pursuee is overwhelming and we see at least a dozen or more helpless civilians shot down during the multiple gun battles.<br /><br />These are the sort of wanton scenes of violence we've all seen 1,000 times.<br /><br />What's good: De Niro is always asking questions, looking at angles, and preparing an escape route. Very believeable and I liked that aspect of his character. I also liked the friendship that developed between Reno and De Niro's characters.<br /><br />What's bad: The car chases are unbelievable. In real life, they would end with death. The gun battles are also hard to fathom - you cannot just run around a city with that much firepower and not get noticed and find yourself in the middle of a massive lockdown. The wanton destruction and ensuing escapes were too many too close together.<br /><br />In the end, I let myself enjoy the story because it had good dialogue and good acting and that was enough to (barely) cover up my lack of suspension of disbelief. I was left wondering what was in that case that was worth so many lives.d dialogue and good acting and that was enough to (barely) cover up my lack of suspension of disbelief. I was left wondering what was in that case that was worth so many lives.
B000FBGBPC|4.0|On Three Days Grace's latest release \\"One-X\\", the alt-metal Canadian quartet doesn't succeed by taking their music to new heights; they succeed by refining the sound that works for them.  Though the slicing guitars are there along with the growling bass and drums, Three Days Grace does show some diversity as they tear through 12 songs whose themes focus on personal struggles, ill-fated relationships, and rallying cries to those who might not otherwise think life is worth living.  The disc starts out strong enough before it stutters for a couple of tracks in the middle.  You get the feeling that the two weakest tracks \\"Let It Die\\" and \\"Over and Over\\" are spawns of some of 3DG's top 40 radio success.  They're tracks that are pop-metal readymade for appeal to a broader audience.  For the most part though, the band sticks to its roots, and finishes the album with 3 of its strongest tracks.   <br />      <br />On the album \\"One-X\\", Three Days Grace front man Adam Gontier still has dark places to explore in his lyrics and he does so with grit and pain in his voice.  Adam's obviously been disillusioned by a broken relationship as is apparent on tracks \\"Let It Die\\", \\"Over and Over\\", and \\"Gone Forever\\".  You get the impression that maybe that broken relationship causes him to evaluate himself as he dabbles in self-disgust on \\"Animal I Have Become\\" and \\"Time of Dying\\", but as he expresses himself in \\"Pain\\" he concludes, \\"I'd rather feel pain than nothing at all.\\"  Lest you think Gontier as a hopeless individual, he shines a bright side of unity for others on \\"Riot\\" and \\"Never Too Late\\".  He ties it all together for the title track \\"One-X\\" as he preaches \\"We are the ones/ we stand above the crowd\\".  Indeed, Three Days Grace does on their latest 4-star release.   <br /> <br />Song-by-song Breakdown: <br /> <br /> 1.  It's All Over [4.5/5] - A great opening track with a rarity from 3DG: a soaring guitar solo <br /> <br /> 2.  Pain [4.5/5] - Strong song with an infectious chug-chug, swaying chorus  <br /> <br /> 3.  Animal I Have Become [4.5/5] - The radio hit still sounds fresh with its thumping bassline and choppy guitar <br /> <br /> 4.  Never Too Late [3/5] - Mid-tempo track laden with acoustic guitar and a chorus laced with hopeful words from lead singer Adam Gontier.  Nothing too new here; sounds like any alt band could have written this one. <br /> <br /> 5.  On My Own [5/5] - As the title suggests Adam has been left on his own by his once girlfriend.  That means you're in for a sampling of his heartfelt, angst-propelled vocals that sneer of his dissatisfaction.   <br /> <br /> 6.  Riot [4/5] - A guitar riff reminiscent of 80's metal fuels this obligatory anthem for the moshers at live shows.  The song's chorus line, \\"Let's start a riot, start a riot,\\" says it all. <br /> <br /> 7.  Get Out Alive [5/5] - A more melodic tune that builds itself around anxious lyrics. <br /> <br /> 8.  Let It Die [2.5/5] - The weakest track on the album leads you to think you're listening to Eve 6 for a minute.  This is a place where 3DG needs to tread carefully, or not at all. <br /> <br /> 9.  Over and Over [3/5] - Spurts of a string section throughout this song.  This is the point on the album where 3DG begins experimenting with their sound a little, without any great results at first. <br /> <br />10.  Time of Dying [5/5] - One of the heavier tracks on the album that sounds as if it could have fit in perfectly on their first album. <br /> <br />11.  Gone Forever [5/5] - Sounds like it could almost be a sequel to \\"Wake Up\\" from the first album.  Judging by the lyrics, you get a sense that Adam is still hitting the bottle to ease the pains of love lost with a drunken stupor.  But with writing like this, we definitely don't mind. <br /> <br />12.  One-X [5/5] - The title track is the perfect closer for this album as it unites all the messages of \\"One-X\\".  Expresses a feeling of hope atop some experimental introduction and verse parts.  A decent guitar solo in the middle of the song as well.  Ends with a sing-a-long chant of, \\"We stand above the crowd!\\"
B000EPR7NE|4.0|Being a huge fan of movie sound tracks I often buy titles just on the name of the artist.  Hans Zimmer is one composer that I will almost alway pick up no matter what the movie is (he's no John Williams or Jerry Goldsmith, but then again who is?).  The Da Vinci Code is not his usual action epic and he composes with a less militaristic and less rapid pace than usual, and it pays off well.  It is a movie score where one can enjoy 90% of the tracks whether or not they've seen the movie.  Track 13 is the best of the score and well worth the price of the CD.  Not Zimmer's best, but a hell of a good listen and well worth the price. Highly recommended to lovers of movie scores and/or classical orchestral music.

B000F39MAQ|3.0|This production is inadequate in almost every respect, except vocally. The stage design and dramatic direction is incoherent and unconvincing. An almost bare set, modern dress and a few masks is not enough to re-create the dramatic world of Traviata. The large clock which dominates the right side of the stage is a continual reminder of the intrusiveness and inappropriateness of the stage direction. Someone who did not know the story of Traviata (if such a person exists!) would not be able to deduce it from this production. <br /> <br />Musically, while the Vienna Philharmonic play beautifully and precisely as always, the musical direction by Carlo Rizzi is equally unconvincing, lacking tension and dynamic contrasts. Compare the same orchestra under the late, great Carlos Kleiber in his DG recording, to hear how the opera should be conducted, with precision, tension and dramatic momentum. <br /> <br />However, ultimately this production is saved by its singers. Rolando Villazon is a splendid Alfredo, and Thomas Hampson, as always, brings distinction and dramatic intelligence to the role of Giorgio. Anna Netrebko demonstrates that she is more than just a stunning young woman (which of course she is). She sings with power and a purity of tone, and throws off the coloratura arias with absolute confidence. The only reservation is that she looks and sounds just too healthy to be taken for a consumptive  courtesan, and bounces around the stage like a hyper-active teenager. (There is a lot of overacting from all the principals - if you can imagine overacting in opera! - which can also be attributed to the director.) Vocally, while extremely impressive, Netrebko does not offer too many dynamic contrasts. You would imagine from listening to her that most of Violetta's arias are marked \\"forte\\", and while she dazzles with her technique and power, she does not convince emotionally when the score calls for pathos and vulnerability. I sometimes felt I was watching Brunnhilde or Elektra rather than Violetta. And yet I continued to watch, despite these criticisms, mainly due to Netrebko's physical and vocal presence.  <br /> <br />This is a production which can be recommended only with serious reservations. It does not replace the Gheorghiu/Solti DVD, which is virtually unsurpassable, with Gheorgiu displaying all the vocal strengths of Netrebko, but adding more character and vulnerability to the role and, in my opinion, having a more distinctive and attractive voice. The production is also close to ideal and Solti's conducting is excellent. The Zeffirelli film version with Domingo and Stratas would be the second choice on DVD. This new version can only be recommended as a supplement to the two mentioned above, as a record of a young Netrebko's impressively robust portrayal of the consumptive Violetta.

0156030209|3.0|Yann Martel's Life of Pi starts when an elderly man says, \\"I have a story that will make you believe in God.\\" Life of Pi and its story does just the opposite; it questions the roots of faith with its central metaphor of the floating island. <br /> <br />The central character, Pi, whose real name Piscene (pool) has been distorted in childhood to Pissing assumes a name that measures the diameter of a circle, the symbol of omniscience, omnipresence, and omnipotence.  Pi tells two stories of being lost at sea--one story of a miraculous survival for 277 days of a boy on a boat with a Bengal tiger and another story of cannibalism and murder on that same boat whose occupants are Pi, a cook, Pi's mother, and a Taiwanese sailor.  Pi says, \\"So tell me . . .which is the better story?  And so it goes with God.\\"  Life of Pi concludes with the investigators for the shipwreck's cause choosing the first story in which the caged animals somehow all escaped from their cages as the ship Tsimtsum sank suddenly to the bottom of the Pacific as the more believable, but is the reader to do so? <br /> <br />Before choosing to believe the first story, Mr. Chiba, one of the investigators, makes associations between the hyena in the first story and the cook in the second; he sees the zebra in the first as the Taiwanese sailor in the second.  The orangutan in the first was Pi's mother in the second, and the tiger Richard Parker from the first is Pi in the second.  Then Mr. Chiba asks, \\"What about the island?  Who are the meerkats?  What about the teeth?  I don't know.  I am not inside this boy's head.\\" <br /> <br />Well, that acidic, man-eating island that spews up dead fish bodies by turning salty water into fresh water and its nave meerkats that don't  run from the tiger's slaughter but act as if slaughter is to be expected are the heart of Life of Pi.  Fish are Christian symbols and Pi observes the meerkats bending over the pool looking for the fish and ties the meerkats into other faithssuccinctly, \\"To see so many beings bending down at the same time reminded me of prayer time in a mosque.\\" The tree in the middle of the island holds one fruit buried in countless leaves that turns out be not a fruit at all but a set of teeth belonging to a man who died and was absorbed by the tree.  Is this island with its nonbearing fruit trees a paradise, an Eden or is its offering merely survival on algae and dead fish?  The meerkats, Pi, and the tiger all flee from its acidic soil in the nighttime but return in the day.  Yann Martel's book portrays a harsh relationship between man and his universe as the tiger, Richard Parker, and Pi compete for survival and yearn for companionship.  Its affirmation of God is only in man's choosing to believe the story. <br />

B000E1ZBGS|2.0|Another example of the contemporary inability to render a classic in anything like its original intent, sense or form. Here we have a parade of third millennium anachronisms almost as preposterous as those on display in the equally absurd current rendering of \\"Tristan and Isolde.\\" Thus, our heroine Kiera Knightley sails through the whole film with a saucy, feminist tinged, \\"cat that swallowed the canary,\\" facial expression and vocal delivery, that suggest that she has been watching a great deal of Katie Couric and Elizabeth Vargas, and is dying to drop the word \\"empowerment,\\" somewhere into her dialogue. <br /> <br />Then there's the \\"incomparable,\\" Judi Dench--(as the publicity breathlessly assures us). For some incomprehensible reason, contemporary casting directors' are under the lamentable delusion that Miss Dench, (like Maggie Smith) is somehow suited to grande dame roles--when nothing could be further from the truth. <br /> <br />Having seen Miss Dench on stage in a five hour production of \\"Cymbeline,\\" at Stratford on Avon, I can personally attest to her range and power as an actress. However, whatever her qualifications for Shakespeare, there is nothing in her appearance or deportment that is remotely aristocratic in the 18th/19th century sense of the term. <br /> <br />Indeed, if anything, her persona is pronouncedly proletariat. <br /> <br />Add to that her coarse and rubicund complexion, (un-pancaked in the current naturalistic mode) and her Lady Catherine appears more like a refugee from a Hogarthian gin palace than the daunting and imperious creature Miss Austen intended. <br /> <br />Martita Hunt where are you now that we need you?  <br /> <br />There is little to say about Donald Sutherland in the role of Mr. Bennet, inasmuch as he has built a successful career out of being miscast--a feat he continues with this role. And his wife in the picture, (far from the lavender, rose silk and cream Mary Boland of yore) looks like a blowsy, overage bawd from thecast of a backwoods dinner theater production of \\"Moll Flanders,\\" who has somehow wandered onto the wrong movie set. <br /> <br />But mercifully we at length arrive at the priceless (and now requisite) final clinch, where Miss Knightley and Mr. Macfadyen are depicted in the lotus position on a lake in front of their chteau, where they proceed to launch into a demonstration of mutual affection that looks like a TV promo for \\"The Bachelor,\\" and makes one wonder if Brad Pitt and Julia Roberts are standing just outside of camera range whispering instructions. <br /> <br />For now if you absolutely require a filmed alternative to the novel itself--stick with the 1940 Greer Garson or unfairly ignored 1979 British TV version.

B000002J2F|5.0|I've been a big Genesis fan ever since the release of their 1980 album, Duke. Before that, I really didn't understand any of their work. Too artsy, too intellectual. It was on Duke where Phil Collins' presence became more apparent. I think Invisible Touch was the group's undisputed masterpiece. It's an epic meditation on intangibility. At the same time, it deepens and enriches the meaning of the preceding three albums. Listen to the brilliant ensemble playing of Banks, Collins and Rutherford. You can practically hear every nuance of every instrument. In terms of lyrical craftsmanship, the sheer songwriting, this album hits a new peak of professionalism.  Take the lyrics to Land of Confusion. In this song, Phil Collins addresses the problems of abusive political authority. In Too Deep is the most moving pop song of the 1980s, about monogamy and commitment. The song is extremely uplifting. Their lyrics are as positive and affirmative as anything I've heard in rock.  Phil Collins' solo career seems to be more commercial and therefore more satisfying, in a narrower way. Especially songs like In the Air Tonight and Against All Odds. But I also think Phil Collins works best within the confines of the group, than as a solo artist, and I stress the word artist. This is Sussudio, a great, great song, a personal favorite.

B000F3A7LE|5.0|About this time, the time of Exposure's original release, there was a homeless fellow on a street corner in downtown Seattle who, each day, went to work informing the uniformly disinterested public that \\"The Air is Alive and Moving.\\" My friends and I tended to acknowledge this observation as both true and self-evident.<br /><br />If there is a single record -- and now a single record brilliantly restored -- that managed to integrate the countless ideas and directions available as they cut their various arcs through the culture and music at that time, it is \\"Exposure\\". Like few other records and even fewer musicians, Fripp shows us again that there's no sane reason to become satisfied with any single form of expression, any formulaic solution to the combination and recombination of elements that, when acted out in honesty, result in music. By bucking that most sacred aspiration of the music industry -- adherence to well-defined categorization -- we listeners were the ones being exposed. Exposed to found material. Exposed to the open loop on top of the closed beat. Exposed to personal and neighborly strife. Exposed to failure and success. Exposed to pop meets art music and a few big laughs. Exposed to the virtuosic in the divine and the banal.<br /><br />Ears wide open, Fripp puts on a show that literally encapsulates virtually every trend and idea still floating around the outskirts of alternative musics today. The resultant energy, range, pathos and humor that comprise the emotional carriage of \\"Exposure\\", along with the now famous and badge-of-honor worthy legal battles the work triggered within The Industry, are all earmarks of a record that is both of and about music free of categorization. We owe Fripp big time for doing it once, and again for his decades-long persistence in getting it to finally be what he knew it should always be.
B000FVQM2Y|5.0|Remember how many top-ten lists Mysterious Skin (also starring Joseph Gordon-Levitt) made last year-end? This will happen again, with BRICK. This is frequently compared with Donnie Darko, not in content but in the cult-following it garnered even tho it didn't make huge box-office waves. In fact, Brick stayed in the top ten in the UK for weeks this spring/summer. But enough PR, the film stands on its own merits, on so many levels: for its concept, script, performances, music, photography. Not to be missed.
B00005YW4H|5.0|Norah has a real voice, a little bit Jazzy, a little bit Folksy, a little bit Bluesy.  A true voice without the special effects.  This is not a singer who tries to sing out of her range, but a singer who understands her voice, and what it can do.  Very pleasant listening for an evening alone, or with a special someone.  I feel that the true voice singer has become such a rarety, and thus a great, great pleasure, when heard.  She is backed by a very capable set of musicians who add to the over all pleasure one derives from listening to this beautiful voice.  My overall favorite piece is, \\"I Don't Know Why\\".  But alas the pure voice singer I fear is destine to go the way of the Handcrafter, extinct.  Listen to a few samples, then download, or pick up a copy, if you like what you hear, and enjoy.
B000F6IOC0|3.0|I'm not in much of a mood for writing a full, good review, so here's a few random bullet points that ought to sum it up.<br /><br />-'Underworld: Evolution' looks cool, but not as cool as the original. B000EF5NAS|5.0|Every decade has its chick flicks that define those years and feature a who's who of up-and-coming actresses mixed with veterans. In the 1980s, it was Steel Magnolias and in the 1990s it was Fried Green Tomatoes, a southern folktale based on the novel by Fannie Flagg (who also co-wrote the screenplay).<br /><br />Fried Green Tomatoes is a beautiful shot film that really evokes the rich, lush setting of the Deep South. Director Jon Avnet also uses warm colours to create an inviting atmosphere that draws the audience in. There is real artistic integrity to the camerawork which gives the film a Classic Hollywood vibe.<br /><br />Fried Green Tomatoes is the perfect lazy Sunday summer afternoon movie that evokes simpler times. The film makes us appreciate taking the time out of our busy lives to stop and smell the roses as it were. The film espouses a simple yet important message of tolerance and compassion towards one another but not in a preachy way. It is a message that is certainly applicable today (maybe even more so) making Fried Green Tomatoes even more relevant.<br /><br />There are a collection of \\"Deleted Scenes\\" that are really just little bits of added footage tagged on at the end of or in-between scenes. There is nothing too memorable here.<br /><br />Also included, is an amusing collection of \\"Outtakes,\\" featuring flubs and blown lines.<br /><br />\\"Moments of Discovery: The Making of Fried Green Tomatoes\\" is an engaging, endearing retrospective documentary that runs just over an hour. Good news for fans is that Mary Stuart Masterson and Mary-Louise Parker contribute new interviews and warmly recall filming anecdotes, including working in the intense Georgian heat, how Masterson really handled all those bees and Parker's run-in with some nasty leeches. This is a must-watch for any fan of this movie.<br /><br />\\"Sipsey's Recipes\\" include actual recipes for over 15 dishes that are taken from Flagg's book and that allow you to recreate the Whistle Stop Caf&eacute;'s cuisine. This is a really nice touch.<br /><br />\\"Jon Avnet's Director's Notes\\" includes script excerpts with specific directions he used as a guide when making the movie.<br /><br />There are \\"Production Photographs\\" that include behind-the-scenes pics of the delicious food and also the movie crew at work.<br /><br />\\"Poster Campaign\\" features various poster designs for the movie, including some really nice hand-drawn ones that are quite artistic in nature.<br /><br />Finally, there is an audio commentary by director Jon Avnet. He takes us through his filmmaking process switching back and forth between talking about the themes of the film and production anecdotes.top Caf's cuisine. This is a really nice touch. <br /> <br />\\"Jon Avnet's Director's Notes\\" includes script excerpts with specific directions he used as a guide when making the movie. <br /> <br />There are \\"Production Photographs\\" that include behind-the-scenes pics of the delicious food and also the movie crew at work. <br /> <br />\\"Poster Campaign\\" features various poster designs for the movie, including some really nice hand-drawn ones that are quite artistic in nature. <br /> <br />Finally, there is an audio commentary by director Jon Avnet. He takes us through his filmmaking process switching back and forth between talking about the themes of the film and production anecdotes.
B000EPR7NE|5.0|The instant I learned that Hans Zimmer was replacing James Horner to score The Da Vinci Code, the soundtrack became my most-anticipated one of the year. Sure, Superman Returns will be quite the musical spectacle: broad and sweeping, no doubt. But the heroic motifs employed for that score must fit within the musical ideas that moviegoers already associate with the Man-of-Tomorrow (ie: the themes John Williams wrote). Composer Brian Ottman has creative license, obviously, but there's only so much room to move in a project like this. Same with other blockbusters this year, like Pirates 2 and Mission Impossible, for instance. Even the flop Posiedon had a musical niche already carved for it (which Klaus Badelt allowed himself to be \\"sucked\\" into). But with the Code, German composer Hans Zimmer (arguably one of the top 3 best soundtrack composers of all time) was able to create an entirely unique sound. He did not have to sound a certain way; HE got to decide how the music SHOULD sound. <br /> <br />And it is a beautiful sound! <br /> <br />The opening cue \\"Dies Mercurii I Martius\\" sets the pacing of the entire soundtrack. Heavy on the choir (this particular cut focuses on the female) with a steady underscore of violins (Hugh Marsh handles the electric violin). The soundtrack differs mightily from typical Zimmer fare in that it relies more on subtle harmonies and intricate string compositions than it does on heavy brass and wild synths. Still, this opening track contains the soundtrack's main theme, which is really a theme for the Grail, itself, and this is a powerful theme. While its full glory is never experienced till the second-to-last cut, \\"Dies Mercurrii\\" gives the general idea, before tailing off into Silas' motif. The latter is a series of brooding chords which suddenly crescendo into a wild 6-note violin theme used to accentuate the on-screen rites of the albino monk as he tortures himself (in the name of God). <br /> <br />The second track is primarily a mood setting. Strings play steadily throughout, and an 8-note brass motif adds some power. Track 3 opens like the first cue did, slowly building off of intermittant choral bursts until the music launches into Silas' theme. The electric violin here is haunting, and the images of self-flagellation--as Silas beats himself yet again--are intensified by the music. <br /> <br />The fourth cue \\"Fructus Gravis\\" is a discovery piece, and certainly one of the CD's highlights. At 2:49 it is the second-shortest on the CD, but I would have appreciated more. Unlike the longest cue \\"Daniel's 9th Cipher\\" at 9 1/2 minutes, \\"Fructus Gravis\\" is very interesting. It contains a splendid female soloist, and a riveting bit of chase music that gives us the Zimmer brass explosions he's famous for. <br /> <br />At just over six minutes \\"Ad Arcana\\" is a delightful piece. Mysterious and full of wonder, the piano variation of the first track's opening motif is a nice touch, and is beautifully enhanced by a harp. A Schindler's List-type violin solo adds a mournful voice, but it is distinctly religious--like the rest, and paints vivid pictures of towering cathedrals and large stain-glass windows. <br /> <br />Tracks 7 and 8 consist mostly of choirs, though the latter cue offers the first re-emergence of the Grail theme since track #1. \\"Poisoned Chalice\\" is the next one, though, and it is gorgeous. Religious, to the core, with a soaring female chorus. Half-way through, two female voices pick up the underscoring, and do it beautifully, showing once again, how the human voice is the world's most powerful, emotion-engendering instrument known to humanity! <br /> <br />\\"The Citrine Cross\\" contains a \\"jerky\\" stop-n-go variation of Silas' theme, as we are treated to its brazen motif for the third time. The choir is also more percussive here than at any other time; roiling with intensity, perhaps echoing the undying, ruthless passion of Silas, the misguided monk. Chimes distort the chorus at times, making for amore \\"chilling\\" sound, but it is applicable to the soundtrack. <br /> <br />\\"Rose of Arimathea\\" is dominated by the male chorus (a first in this score), and there is a somber bit here that is reminiscent of The Shining's classic horror soundtrack. Again, the religiousity of the movie's musical score is highlighted. <br /> <br />The second to last instrumental cue is entitled \\"Beneath Alrischa,\\" and it really only serves as a 4 minute, 23 second build up to the last cut \\"Chevaliers de Sangreal\\" which is the re-occurence of the \\"Grail Theme.\\" It is a loud and powerful outburst of brass and violins; an amazing \\"last hurrah\\" to a powerful soundtrack. <br /> <br />Filmtracks' review commented that \\"The best ... moments of awe should be credited to the chorus, which exists in both the higher ethereal female ranges and the deep chanting male depths that resurrect the broad scope of Crimson Tide. Zimmer's thematic development is subtle at every turn.\\" <br /> <br />In the end, I highly recommend this score, especially to the soundtrack purist. <br /> <br />RATING: **** 1/2 (out of 5)
B0000029GA|5.0|Vintage Nas + Instant Classic. What more can be said about Illmatic?   Here's my 2 cents. I think what separates Illmatic from a lot of the other great classics is that the album flows seamlessly together, very cohesive as if it's one well written movie or book. It's very identical to Eric B. & Rakim's \\"Paid in Full\\" in that respect. My favorites are Memory Lane, World is Yours, Represent, It aint hard to tell, One Love, New York State of Mind, Life's a B. Nas set a precedent for himself with Illmatic. Face it- He will have more hit singles, but he has yet been able to recapture fully the glory of Illmatic's cohesive-ness. I hope so because that's what the world wants to hear from him. Tell us how the little boy from the Queensbridge projects sees the world  now that he's in his early 30's and capture that. Talk about life's past hurdles and future foreseen ones as it relates to the 70/80's kids. Trim the fat and filler tracks and then we will have the real sequel to Illmatic.

0140042520|5.0|I've read criticism of this book that I found just did not hold water. Most who don't care for it complain that there is a shadow of commercialism hanging over it because after the success of ON THE ROAD, his publisher asked specifically for something \\"like ON THE ROAD\\" and so he delivered THE DHARMA BUMS. As if this single fact (even if true, which I somehow doubt) has any bearing on the quality of the writing or the success of how Kerouac expressed the ideas within the work.<br /><br />To me, it is one of the most successful of Kerouac's novels. The writing is extremely powerful and seems to echo after you put the book away. I also find it to be the most transporting of his books--there is a feeling of almost being in some of the places he describes. In this way, as far as place, it's more effective than his more well-known and widely admired pieces.<br /><br />This novel means a lot to me. It never fails to inspire me, and I often take a copy along when I go backpacking into a National Park or wilderness area.
B000ENC6XM|3.0|I never bothered to watch this movie until the HD DVD came out and now I know why.  While the movie is not terrible, there is absolutely nothing memorable about it.  I just watched it last night and am having a hard time recalling the plot.  Keanu Reeves plays John Constantine, a man condemned to Hell for trying to kill himself and trying to attain redemption by banishing demons back to the underworld. The rest of the cast, including Rachel Weisz, was fine, the special effects were good, and there were even a few funny moments.  I was never too bored while watching it, but in the end it left me feeling empty.  The HD DVD transfer is one of the better ones, but this movie is a rental at best. <br />
B000055QBX|5.0|Omar and Cedric must have figured out some black magic before they recorded this one with the boys. From the opening distorted and processed squalls materializing from Omar's guitar on \\"Arc Arsenal,\\" every time a listener rides ATDI's wave on this one it is a mysteriously thrilling experience. One can only say this about a release or two every year. I mean, really, I got this when it came out six years ago (the hyperkinetic video to \\"One-Armed Scissor\\" prompted me [see it on _This Station Is Non-Operational_]) and I've never looked back. While I no longer play it three times a day like I did then (never been bored listening after literally hundreds of listenings), I think it's something more like once a month that I listen to it these days. And it's right back into the headbanging, the chills, singing/screaming along with lyrics that still don't make perfect sense to me (\\"intravenously polite/ it was the walkie-talkies that knocked the pins down/ as her shoes gripped the dirt floor/ in the silhouette of dying\\"--\\"Invalid Litter Dept.\\"), but will nonetheless grow with me for the rest of my life, like Joyce's _Finnegans Wake_ or poems by Celan.<br /><br />Really, this is as good as anything Mars Volta has done (MV is my favorite operating band followed closely by Radiohead and Wilco--hallowed company!). _Relationship of Command_ is really the leaping board to the heights unknown they have reached with MV. It is also the culmination of the considerable accomplishments of ATDI, while representing a quantum leap from their nonetheless excellent preceding LP, _In/Casino Out_. What makes it a diving board to MV is the fact that we hear more of the stratospheric guitar from Omar than we had heard on previous ATDI releases and the song-writing and lyrics are leaning more towards byzantine prog tendencies. What makes it still ATDI and the culmination of everything they did is that it is still just punk, except it is refined by Andy Wallace's huge production skills and the band's (especially Omar's and Cedric's) relentlessly visionary drive. To put it in a nutshell, this rocks you on every level: emotional, intellectual, aesthetic, and mostly your BODY: Cedric and Omar didn't thrash around on-stage like possessed dervishes for the show of it (it's that black magic)!<br /><br />This is to say that _Relationship of Command_ is the best \\"punk\\" CD of this decade and I would be stunned (and delighted) to see anyone come to this level by the end of 2009. Really, as far as pure punk CDs go, I can really only think of Patti Smith, the Clash, and a few other stalwarts who created a product this uniformly mind-shattering. If ATDI had stayed together, they may have been able to top this, but, then again, CDs this brilliant only seem to emanate from the kinds of rough straits that the ATDI members were in at this time, and the impending break-up energy must have had everything to do with the manic surge that crackles from every second of the 45 minutes of this CD. Instead, ATDI broke up and Cedric and Omar chose to infuse their punk roots with prog and in turn came up with something different altogether (prunk?).<br /><br />Everyone who has any sort of sincere love for extreme music of any sort has to own this one. And if you're not a lover of extreme music? ATDI may just expand your mind with their William Burroughs-style lyrical approach and unceasingly energetic performance/compositional approach. Put this one in a time capsule with a few other CDs to help define what both \\"punk\\" and \\"rock\\" meant in the first thirty odd years of its existence.nd's (especially Omar's and Cedric's) relentlessly visionary drive. To put it in a nutshell, this rocks you on every level: emotional, intellectual, aesthetic, and mostly your BODY: Cedric and Omar didn't thrash around on-stage like possessed dervishes for the show of it (it's that black magic)! <br /> <br />This is to say that _Relationship of Command_ is the best \\"punk\\" CD of this decade and I would be stunned (and delighted) to see anyone come to this level by the end of 2009. Really, as far as pure punk CDs go, I can really only think of Patti Smith, the Clash, and a few other stalwarts who created a product this uniformly mind-shattering. If ATDI had stayed together, they may have been able to top this, but, then again, CDs this brilliant only seem to emanate from the kinds of rough straits that the ATDI members were in at this time, and the impending break-up energy must have had everything to do with the manic surge that crackles from every second of the 45 minutes of this CD. Instead, ATDI broke up and Cedric and Omar chose to infuse their punk roots with prog and in turn came up with something different altogether (prunk?).  <br /> <br />Everyone who has any sort of sincere love for extreme music of any sort has to own this one. And if you're not a lover of extreme music? ATDI may just expand your mind with their William Burroughs-style lyrical approach and unceasingly energetic performance/compositional approach. Put this one in a time capsule with a few other CDs to help define what both \\"punk\\" and \\"rock\\" meant in the first thirty odd years of its existence.
